dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RITA O’GRADY and her husband EDDIE, both late twenties, step onto the balcony of a flat on a massive housing estate in East London. With them are their two children, GRAHAM and SHARON. They kiss the kids goodbye as another man, also in blue overalls, emerges from the flats, clambers onto a bike and sets off down the car-less streets. Rita and Eddie grab their own bikes, and ride off into an ever broadening stream of people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On another part of the estate, a much younger woman, SANDRA, emerges from a flat, waves to her mum on a balcony above and hops onto her bike. She wobbles off, the white patent leather boots she is wearing make balance something of a challenge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandra filters in with the great tide of cyclists pouring from the Estate beneath the baking sun. We see them from high above. Sandra spots Eddie and Rita, calls out and speeds up to join them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tide has become a flood as more and more cyclists freewheel through town and down a hill towards a massive industrial complex with a blue neon sign above it: FORD MOTORS. As they approach the factory, the cyclists diverge, men one way, women the other. Several people stop and kiss at the point of divergence, including Eddie and Rita. Then he pushes off towards the Main Plant, brand new and state of the art while she turns her bike towards a crumbling nineteen twenties monolith the River Plant. We follow Rita, as she cycles between the blackened, paint peeled buildings to a series of bike racks, There, along with Sandra, Eileen, Brenda and Monica, she dismounts and glancing at the hot sun, passes into the factory. MUSIC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the shop floor, a cramped, filthy, windowless place, chatter and laughter rings out. The girls, nearly 200 of them, roll down their overalls and tie the arms off in front of them, revealing bras or camisoles. And as Rita enters and moves to her bench, we drop to floor level and see that nearly all of the women have now removed their shoes. As Rita, threading up her sewing machine, wipes a bead of sweat away from her face, we understand why: the place is an oven! Rita grabs a box of vinyl pieces as Eileen walks past, revealing a ferocious wired bra.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Bloody hell, Eileen, you got more support there than the Arsenal- Eileen makes to retort but is interrupted by a the sound of a hooter. Almost at once there is the noise of a generator engaging and then a staggering cacophony as 200 sewing machines start to clatter away. Talk impossible, the women get down to work. Rita pulls several pieces from the box beside her and picks up a car headrest frame. She arranges the vinyl around the frame and starts to machine it into place. It is hugely intricate but nevertheless she sews at breathtaking speed and quickly completes the first item. She places it on a trolley behind her and grabs the next frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. The street is utterly deserted. And we see how bare, how basic, how unlike the Swinging Sixties, is Dagenham. And then, we see a lone figure, CONNIE, late forties, cycling towards the plant as fast as she can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita curses. One of her nails is chipped. She wipes sweat away again and resumes her work at a ferocious speed, finishing another headrest. As she reaches for the next frame, Connie enters, flustered-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Sorry I’m late-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (smiles; shouts) Everything alright? Connie looks across from threading her machine.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Just overslept. Connie takes water on the her machine, above with a off her shoes, places a washing up bowl of floor and stands in it. Then she turns to hassled. But, suddenly, something drops from thud. Connie jumps, startled. It is a dead bird, entangled in cotton threads. Already there’s laughter from those who saw the near miss. Connie tenses; staring at the animal on her work bench with a steely expression. She’s not in the mood. Instantly, more laughter.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Least it didn’t shit on you. They do that sometimes. ‘Fore they die. Connie picks up the bird and marches to the bin with it. Rita looks to the rafters where hundreds of other birds hang dead. She then turns back to Connie, trying not to laugh, as she arrives at her place. But immediately, the hooter sounds again and the power to the machines is switched off. The girls start to make themselves decent-

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Ladies...If I could just interrupt you a second- Rita looks to the far doorway. There, a man in his late fifties, in blue overalls, waits, staring at the floor, in a well practised manoeuvre. This is ALBERT FINCHAM.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Stand by your beds, men! The girls laugh but all around there is also a hubbub of excited chatter as they complete getting dressed. Connie, however, hurries down the aisles and shunts the girls forward.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Come on! Hurry up- The noise levels have risen considerably.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get down the front- She claps her hands and shouts to the back rows-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Girls- (turns; shouts) In you come, Albert- He enters and walks to the front. Connie moves across and stands by Albert’s side, facing the girls. He leans into her.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Thank you, Connie- Albert climbs onto a bench and the noise rises accordingly. Voices are calling out: “What’s happening, then? What they decided?” Albert struggles to speak over the top.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah. Alright...Hang on. I’1l...If you’d just shut up a minute! The uieten ( y (More) )

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right, well...to quote Winston Churchill himself: it ain’t the end. It ain’t even the beginnin’ of the end. But it may well be the end of the beg-

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Albert, for fuck’s sake, get on with it- The women laugh. Several call out.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Please! Ladies! I’m doin’ me best here-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shout that he’s lovely when he’s cross. Albert sags but gradually, the girls are quiet. He nods, relieved.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you... (clears throat) So...The deadline we set the management, to respond to our complaint about how they’ve re-graded you...”un- skilled”...has now passed. (voices shout; serious this time) And they still ain’t got back to us- (louder cries) Which means!...you gotta vote! On the threat we made in that original communiqué: an immediate ban on all overtime and a one day stoppage - to happen on the 29th of May. (silence. Eileen glances at Rita, nervously) All them for industrial action: hands up. Rita’s determined face. Her arm goes straight up. She looks round. All of the other hands are up, too.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Against? (no one) Thank you. 187 to nil. I’m seein’ the Management first thing tomorrow mornin’. I’‘1l inform ‘em of your decision. A stunned moment, then as Albert steps down, a huge cheer and applause as and the women break into groups, talking excitedly. Eileen grabs Rita.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: We done it! Rita looks nervous, too.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: First time for everything...

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Fuck ‘em. That’s what I say. Every other bugger round here goes on strike. Why shouldn't we?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Just...maybe don’t put it like that if you get interviewed by David Frost, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone laughs and the girls return to their benches, still chattering furiously. In the doorway, Albert watches the women going back to their positions. A young lad, BRIAN, passes by, sweeping the corridor. Albert looks to him, indicating the girls.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I fought Rommel, you know. I was never once scared like I am when I go in there. The hooter sounds and the machines start up again. Immediately the door slides shut, just as the girls begin to disrobe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sports and social club has been decorated with streamers and balloons. Young Girl by Gary Puckett plays on a large portable record player, perched on the stage at one end of the room. However, the dark suits and knee length skirts of the packed dance floor bring to mind the nineteen fifties, not the sixties. The joint is jumping, nevertheless. And standing at a corner table, Rita throws down a large gin before rushing back to Eddie, caught in the thick of the dancing. Close to him is Connie, with GEORGE, her husband, a couple of years younger, angular and handsome, moving stiffly. Also nearby are Eileen and Dave. Eddie spins Rita rather too vigorously and she nearly goes over, laughing, as he grabs her again. Then, suddenly, the music stops and everyone is plunged into near darkness. Moans and complaints from the floor as a Dave runs towards the record player.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Alright! Hold your horses-—

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: (to Dave) This happens every time- More shouts of derision.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: He puts the wrong fuse in. I keep tellin’ him- Then suddenly a piano sounds out. Heads spin towards the back of the room where the older folk are gathered.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Oh, God! Give him half a chance and he’s in there-

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 6
dialogues.text: Albert is playing “MY OLD MAN.” The oldsters immediately start singing along, to groans from the youngsters.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -Bleedin’ Liberace- But then, the power is back on and Rita puts the record player on again, drowning out Albert. It’s Sandie Shaw's, Always Something There To Remind Me. A big cheer. Rita and the others start dancing. She looks across to a peeved Albert and winks at him. He’s not amused. Eddie leans in-

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Here, where’s Brenda gone? Rita looks uneasy. She shrugs. Eddie nods and whisks her off again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man grunts and thrusts. He’s having sex, eyes shut, across the back seat of his motor. Beneath him, Brenda stares at a tear along the seam of the front passenger seat. The man opens his eyes and finally stops thrusting. At last Brenda looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Your trim. That’ll be hangin’ right off in a day or two, that will... (points to tear on seam) And I bet I know the girl what sowed it, n’all. (nods, smugly. He is stunned) Go on, then. Chop chop. Or we’1ll miss the buffet. He hesitates, then goes for it anyway. Brenda, head rocking, looks back to the edge of the seat: typical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty glasses are placed on a tray.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Right! Who wants another? George? You're finished-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Naah. Be up all night-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Go on! Let your hair down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He relents. Connie pushes her own across.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Same again for me, ta! Rita smiles, just as a figure lurches into her.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Who’s next, then? Sandra, in a much shorter skirt than the others, also with a bee hive hair-do, wears a sash which says 21 TODAY and sways alarmingly.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You sure you don’t wanna sit down five minutes, Sandra?

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: You’re jokin’...

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: What about some food...? (to Eileen) She won’t eat nothin’... (to Sandra) There’s Scotch eggs-

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: (to Rita) I’1l have a snowball...Come on, George. You ain’t tripped the whatsit with me yet, have you? She weaves back onto the floor and is soon involved in something very sixties and very unstable. Rita watches her, then looks back to George uneasily. He starts to move, but it’s an effort-—

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Do you mind, George...If I have this one...? They turn; Albert is staring across at Sandra; he bends to one side, limbering up. Rita smiles at Albert’s gesture. He turns to Connie.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like to keep me hand in...Jitterbug, Twist. All them... He takes a deep breath and prepares to stride out-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, don’t overdo it... (Albert turns to her) Give yourself an heart attack...We need you tomorrow-

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 8
dialogues.text: Albert tuts, piqued. Then he strides out onto the floor. Rita smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandra sways. Then Dave and Eileen take her by either arm and set off, to escort her home. Finally, Rita and Eddie are left alone in the still night air. Rita takes a deep, contented breath. Then she kisses Eddie on the mouth.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: What was that for?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Nothin’. Like you. That’s all... He is staring at her in wonder. And lust. He tries to grab her.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Come here-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Ooy- She skips away, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Ri-ta! She turns and looks back at him.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Not out in the street- She grins and runs off. He chases after her. She easily keeps her distance.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Oh, you’re better than that, are you!

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Yes, I am, actually. Then she goes over on one of her high heels. They laugh together. INT. RITA’S HOUSE, KITCHEN - DAY 12 A big screaming guitar solo from Cream’s Crossroads- And Rita re-tunes the radio, exhaling heavily. She feels dreadful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She settles on Born Free by Matt Monroe, then takes a drag on a fag, finishes ironing a shirt and moves across to a cooker where she removes a pan of beans from the heat. She spoons them onto three plates, eggs and bacon already in place, then pauses again, feeling sick. Rita places the plates on the table. In front of Sharon, her daughter (8) who is reading a comic. Graham, their eleven year old son enters, still in his pyjamas.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Graham...You’re gonna be late-

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I don’t feel very well... Rita frowns, crosses and feels Graham’s forehead.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You’re not hot.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: It’s me stomach. It's said very quickly. Then he tucks into his breakfast. Rita watches and frowns. Graham eats with the fork in his left hand, his right, clenched. She takes it. He resists but Rita fixes him with her gaze and he unclenches his fist as she turns it over. His palm has angry red wields across it. Rita is shocked.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I never done nothin’- (she looks him right in the eye) Honest. She stares. Nods. It’s enough.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Mr Clarke again? He looks uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. Rita holds her temper. Just.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Have your breakfast and go and get dressed- (he makes to speak) I’1l deal with it...It’ll be fine. She says it with utter conviction. He nods, relieved.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 10
dialogues.text: INT. RITA’S HOUSE, BEDROOM - DAY 13 Rita pulls back the sheets on their bed.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Oy! Lover boy! Eddie lies face down on the bed. He wears nylon pyjama bottoms. He moans.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Clear off. I’m dyin’.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: We're all dyin’. And we all gotta go to work...Clean shirt- She drapes it over him. And walks to the door. She looks back. He hasn’t moved. She crosses, removes the shirt and tips a bedside glass of water over his back. He yelps, leaps up and she walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As clouds gather, the men (and only men) go about their business outside. GORDON, late twenties, drives a motorised trolley cart, full of completed seats. They load brand new, shining Ford cars onto transporters. But then, a crack of thunder and it starts to rain-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thunder of the factory. The women work in silence. Sweat drips from Rita’s face and she wipes her brow with her sleeve. She’s moving with her usual speed, but with something else, too; aggression, as she yanks hard at the cotton threads she must cut off from around the headrests. Then there is a moan. She turns. Connie has stopped work and glugs from a bottle of Lucozade.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Never again, I swear. Beside Connie, Eileen re-applies a cold flannel to the back of her neck and Brenda downs a pint of milk. But suddenly, spots of water are dripping through the roof.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh- She looks up and grabs an umbrella which she wedges above her station.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Alley-bloody-lujah-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenda and several other girls step right under the rain, to cool down. Eileen turns to Connie.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: You’1l go mad, takin’ that up and down...It’s showers all day!

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I don’t care...It’s dangerous. Water and electrics...Innit?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: What you talkin’ about? You’re standin’ in a bowl of the bloody stuff! Rita smiles, then sees Sandra who is ashen white, hurriedly place a headrest on the “DONE” trolley, just as it’s pushed away. Rita frowns and grabs the item as the trolley is wheeled behind her. She inspects it.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Con!....Connie! (Connie turns) Sandra's at it again- (indicates a tear) You’re gonna have to say somethin’- Sandra, who blows bubble gum, sees Rita looking and waves. Rita shouts.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t wave you silly cow, I’m moanin’ about you... Rita removes her own item, in order to repair Sandra’s work. Then she looks back to Connie.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We can’t keep coverin’ for her. (Connie looks worried) They’re gonna find out, Con. And then they’1l give her the boot.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I’‘ll have a word.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Connie...Con!- She turns. Albert, wearing a suit and union badge, stands directly in front of them, beaming.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Albert. Then, her eyes indicate the slip she is wearing. And all of the other half dressed girls, too.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ! He looks down, averting his gaze. Rita, grinning, calls out.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Maaaaaaaa-n! The hooter sounds and power is turned off to the benches as the girls dress. But noise remains; excited chatter filling the air. When Albert looks up the whole shop floor has shoved around Connie’s bench.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: You were sayin’?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (instant smile again) Meeting tomorrow. Ford headquarters. Down at Warley! The girls all glance at one another, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: You’re jokin’-

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (posh voice) “The machinists? The machinists are threatening strike action...” They couldn't believe it! (Chatter breaks out on the floor. Albert leans in) Right. They’1l have Hopkins there. Jones. And Grant...He’s a right miserable sod. Which means we need one more. (Eileen frowns) Little principle I learnt in the war, Eileen: success in battle is very simple. Turn up with more on your side than they’ve got on theirs and turn up when they’re least expectin’ it. (back to Connie) In this case we’re booked in for two thirty, so we'll get there at half one...Monty Taylor’1l come from Union head office, I make two, you’re three, so- (smiles; looks round) -who’s gonna be the extra man? Any takers? And instantly all noise has stopped. The girls stare back at Albert uncertainly. He tuts, disappointed. He looks to Brenda.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Fuck off!

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Oh, come on...It’s a day off- All hands go up in the air. Several people call out, too. Albert looks over the rows of faces, just as stymied as before. But then he notices Rita. Their gazes lock again. And he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita wipes down her bench and tosses the off cuttings and threads in a bin. The women are done for the day. She hurries towards the exit. But her way is suddenly blocked, as a forklift truck tows in a massive trailer load of dismantled, un-upholstered seats.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: What you doin’ with them?

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: This new Escort. Looks like they finally designed something people like. The driver jumps down, unhooking the load.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Well they can get fucked! We’ve had our vote! We ain’t doin’ no overtime!

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: Yeah, you took the plunge at last... He doesn’t re-connect the trailer but climbs on board the forklift, anyway, scoffing:

dialogues.speaker: GORDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Me and the boys was sayin’: we’d’ve gone on strike years ago; just havin’ to turn up in a pig hole like this! You know it’s rainin’ in here, don’t you? And he drives off. The women stare at the seats, suddenly aware of what they are doing. Rita, frustrated by the delay, leans in to Connie.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I’1l see you tomorrow-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Rita-

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I gotta go! And she has. Connie hesitates. Then she looks to the girls and walks out. They follow her. Soon all that remains are the seats, un-touched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita is down to her underwear, already in high heels. She slides a pencil skirt on, toppling against the cubicle wall-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Christ- Then she grabs a top- Then she pulls on a top, runs in front of a mirror, checks her teeth and is off-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's stopped raining as Rita slides through a puddle on her bike and stops. She jumps off and leans it against a brick wall. She straightens her blouse and immediately curses: one stocking is smeared with splashed up dirt. She considers her options, then, glancing round, removes it. Then the other one. Then she hurries round a corner and approaches the Thomas A Becket Grammar School. It is much leafier here and cars can be seen for the very first time, most parked near the waiting mothers, gathered at the gate. As Rita strides towards them, short skirted, shapely legged, several women turn to look at her. Rita stiffens slightly. A bell rings and the school starts to let out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A teacher, fifties, cleans a blackboard as Rita enters the classroom.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Mr Clarke? (he turns) I wondered if I could have a word? He considers her.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Of course- He motions to a chair. Rita hesitates; it’s a pupil’s and rather small. She sits anyway. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEACHER (CONT’D) How may I help you? His tone is clipped, Empire. Rita stares at the man. There is no easy way. Finally-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You hit my son. He frowns, confused. But Rita, hearing it said, feels stronger. And more angry.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: On his hand. You caned him. And it ain’t the first time.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Ah. Yes. O’Grady...I remember. He smiles; not the slightest hint of remorse. Rita is wrong footed. He crosses the room- TEACHER (CONT’D) Forgot his protractor. And it isn’t the first time... He nonchalantly collects some books. Rita flares-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I don’t care whether it’s the tenth time! I don’t want you doin’ it! She stops; knows she’s lost her temper but she holds his gaze, nonetheless. He simply smiles, calmly.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Have you spoken to your husband about this, Mrs O'Grady?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (surprised) What?...No...I-

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: I do find where matters of discipline are concerned, that’s usually the best route-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: He’s my son! Again she flinches inwardly. But again he seems calm.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: You live on the estate don’t you? Rita is confused but also on guard now-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I don’t see what-

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: We find that those boys who come to us from the estate often have difficulty in adjusting to the standards of behaviour required in a school like this...It’s not really their fault. Their parents have invariably never undergone the full rigours of academic life- He looks at her quizzically. And now Rita struggles to hold his gaze. The teacher continues, pleased. TEACHER (CONT’D) So the boys can hardly look to them for guidance... Rita tries to keep her expression neutral. TEACHER (CONT’D) But they do adapt...In time...And I’m sure your son will, too. If he’s just given the chance. He smiles, comes across and holds out his hand to shake. Rita stares at it, utterly shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita walks blindly away from the classroom, turns down a corridor and stops. Ahead is a dead end. She quickly retraces her steps, passing back round the corner. Another woman, LISA, waits outside the classroom now. She turns to face Rita. She is of a similar age, thin, and impeccably dressed in expensive high street fashion. She frowns, sensing Rita’s distress.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Are you alright? She speaks with a posh voice. Rita trembles.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Fuck off! Then Rita barges past her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita is shaking, upset and angry. She fumbles in her bag but her packet of fags is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks towards a News Kiosk and steps to the front of a small queue.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Ten John Player, please. (hands across money) Ta. She looks down. A few magazines are laid out on top of a tressel table. One of them is Vogue. It’s cover shows Jean Shrimpton with short, slicked down hair and panda eyes: the sixties of popular memory. The byline reads: ALL CHANGE. Rita picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And this, thank you. She stands tall as she passes it over.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 22
dialogues.text: INT. RITA’S HOUSE - NIGHT 23 TV pictures of The Prague Spring. A Czech student drops a flower down the barrel of a soldier’s gun.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Russia said it was monitoring the situation closely- Audio fades.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Tea’s ready... Sharon looks round from the telly. Rita stands by the door, a tea towel in her hands. Eddie is dozing on the sofa and starts to rouse himself. Graham is at a table by the wall where he is doing his homework. He turns and Rita smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alright? Need any help?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Naah. It’s easy. He packs his stuff up. Rita looks at him guiltily. But then he turns suddenly and sees her staring.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Nothin’...You’re a good lad. That’s all.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 18
dialogues.text: She ducks away from his gaze and moves to the TV. We see that it is now showing an episode of The Magic Roundabout; Sharon has turned over. But Rita switches off.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Aw, mum- Rita steps back into the kitchen. Eddie picks Sharon up as he passes her. She giggles.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here, Dad, Martine Clarke’s got colour. I seen it-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start to sit round the table.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, we’ll have colour soon. Once you can rent ‘em- Rita looks to Eddie who takes up his knife and fork.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Eddie...We can’t go talkin’ about colour. We ain’t paid for the fridge yet. And the three piece is still on tick. (he frowns; so?) And now we got all this unrest at work.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (realising; laughing) That! You had a vote, Rita. Unrest’s when you actually come out and strike! Rita’s face falls and Eddie looks immediately guilty.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, come on! Don’t look like that. I’m only jokin’...I’m proud of you. We all are...Stickin’ to your guns...We had a book goin’ on the shop floor: no one thought you’d even take the vote. So- (nods positively) Well done! Sharon smiles at her mother, too. Rita looks from her, back to Eddie. She isn’t sure quite how to take the comment and finally she shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Well...It ain’t just a vote now. We got a meetin’ tomorrow. With all the bosses...And I’m goin’. Her family stare back, stunned. She avoids eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So...I'll plate your tea up, in the mornin’. Then if I’m a bit late back, you'll just need to heat it through. Eddie nods relieved. And Rita feels suddenly piqued.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Apparently we go to a Berni Inn. On our way there. She takes a mouthful of her own food, still looking at Eddie, a twinkle in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Connie, Rita, Albert and Monty enter the Berni Inn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red velour and a deep blue carpet. And in a far corner of the restaurant, Rita and Connie, facing Albert and Monty around a table. The two men wear dark suits, Rita and Connie smart dresses; both have their hair set. Monty reaches across and pours more Blue Nun into a wine glass beside his empty pint pot. Then he carries on talking to Albert in hushed tones. Rita finishes a slice of Black Forest gateaux and moans with delight.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: It's alright, innit?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: And that steak...

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (whispering) It's Monty, insists we come here, you know...Long as the union’s payin’... Rita smiles. Just as Monty leans across.

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: Here, Rita...Word of advice- He stops; uses the corner of the menu to poke between his teeth. Rita stares.

dialogues.speaker: MONTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -when we get there. Don’t be lured in. If they seem to be askin’ you a question, just look at your notebook and I’11 have it. Above all, if I nod, you nod.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 20
dialogues.text: Albert stares at Rita. She nods. But he keeps his eye on her. However, Monty waves to a waiter-

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Monty?

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: What? Thought we’d have one o’ them liqueur coffees. Panatella maybe-

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Yeah. We could...It’s just...If we don’t go now, we’ll end up bein’ on time. Monty considers Albert. The waiter arrives.

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Just the bill please. Albert glances at Rita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young secretary rushes about her office.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: I...I’m sorry...We weren’t expecting you until- She checks her appointments book. Albert and the others are crowded around her desk, just inside the office.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: That's quite alright.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: I’m not sure Mr Hopkins-

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Honestly. It’s not a problem. Just let him know, we’re here, anyway...At half past. As arranged. (She looks confused, then hurries to an inner door) And there’s four of us. If you need an extra chair. Rita smiles slightly, looking to Albert; sly old dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Rita exhales, frustrated. She sits in a dark, hot room with no windows. It is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER HOPKINS Ford’s Head of Industrial Relations, late thirties, sits beside two other men,GRANT and JONES both middle aged, facing Monty, Albert, Rita and Connie. Rita glances at the clock. Four fifteen. A black suited PENTHOUSE STEWARDESS serves tea and coffee, no one says thank you except Rita. Finally-

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: On a previous occasion, in a free vote, the girls agreed to the new grading structure-—

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: They did not agree, however, as to where they would end up on it. Which is why we're sittin’ round this table! Silence again. Rita fidgets.

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: Look. I understand what the girls are saying. I just don’t think that they appreciate-

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: I'd rather you didn’t speak for the girls, Mr Hopkins...None of us here knows what's in their heads. That comment makes Rita look across. She turns to Connie. Her eyes are firmly on her note pad still.

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: The fact remains, there is a formal grievance procedure already in place. And the machinists’ case will be heard. What we can’t do, is let them jump the queue- (Rita frowns) -or every other Ford employee who is waiting on a decision, will want our blood!

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: Peter. Look...You know me. I ain’t got no axe to grind with Ford. Am I right or am I right?

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: You’ve always been very fair.

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: Exactly...And we’re all men of the world so- Rita looks to Albert. This is getting too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONTY (CONT’D) -let’s cut to the chase, shall we? We’1l agree to re-convene in two weeks time- Albert stiffens. Rita looks appalled.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Monty?-

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: Wait. Listen...We’ll re-convene...and we'll come back down here again for the day...And at that point, you’1ll guarantee to look into the girls’ complaint.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: The thing is, Monty-

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: That way...you can go back to your bosses and say the strike’s off, ‘cause of how you handled today’s negotiations...and we can go back to the girls and say they’re now your number one priority...In a few weeks time. Hopkins glances at the other Ford men; counts to three.

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: That seems very fair.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I’m not sure the girls-

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: The girls'll be fine! So long as they know they’re not just gettin’ fobbed off by the management: the unions’s settin’ the terms. That’s what matters-—

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bollocks! All heads turn. And Rita blinks. But it’s said. And she means it, she realises. She turns-—

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry Albert but...It is. Bollocks...Three hours, we’ve been sittin’ here now and- (to Monty) “That's what matters to the girls?” How're you qualified to talk about what matters? To us?... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (looks to Connie who stares back amazed) What matters is this- She reaches into her bag and throws a pile of vinyl cuttings, of the kind we saw her machine at the start, in front of Hopkins.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There. You put them together- (spreads them out) 13 different bits. That makes up an head rest cover...

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Ford property, I believe-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Oh, get stuffed- (to Hopkins; on track) What matters is that we have to take them 13 different bits of material and imagine how they fit together...’cause there ain’t no template...and then we have to sew ‘em, all free hand, into the finished article! Same with seat covers and door trim. And that is not unskilled work. Which is how you've re-graded us! Christ, you have to take an exam to get on our line-

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: Please, Miss-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Mrs!...O’Grady.

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: Mrs O'Grady, I understand your grievance. But-—

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Oh, no! No, no, no, no...Don’t start with all that again; all that I appreciate, I sympathise...It ain’t difficult: we’re entitled to semi-skilled. And the wages what go with it- (Hopkins makes to speak) And!...as regards queue jumpin’, we put this complaint in months ago- (Albert is impressed) -and you done nothin’ about it. And we both know why you done nothin’ n’all, don’t we? ‘Cause we’re women and the women have never gone on strike. This is the first time we've even suggested it. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Which meant you thought you could keep ignorin’ us...Well, hard bleedin’ cheese, mate, ‘cause it’s too late now! Albert's face. And Connie's.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We’re gonna do what we said we would. No more overtime and an immediate twenty four hour stoppage. And where it goes from here, that’s up to you. Cause we only open our gobs when we mean it! Rita stands. A moment. The others stand too, dazed. The meeting is clearly over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita drags on a cigarette by Albert's car, an old Ford Corsair. She looks worried. Connie is with her. She looks nervous too. The reason is about twenty yards away, by a phone box: Albert being railed at by Monty. After a moment Monty storms into the box and dials. Albert walks back.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: He’s calling Branch. Tellin’ ‘em what you said.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (nods ) He seems a bit... She shrugs, awkwardly. They all look back to the phone box. Monty rants. Then Albert fixes Rita with a stare and points a spindly finger. And he grins.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I knew....I knew. Up there- (taps head. She frowns) I wanted clever, Rita. That’s why I picked you. (she is stunned) Bringin’ them cuttin’s in, though...that was magnificent...I didn’t expect that: you'd come prepared-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Oh, no. No. Grant was right. I was nickin’ them...Eddie uses ‘em to patch up his tent. For when we go campin’... She nods at Albert apologetically. He stares.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well...All the same...

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 25
dialogues.text: And he walks off with as much dignity as he can muster. At the car, he turns. He looks Rita in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Leave Monty to me. Rita is wrong footed by Albert’s rapid re-focusing. Connie steps forward-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: And what about the factory? The girls. What you gonna say to them?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I’m not gonna say anythin’, Con. You're in charge on the shop floor. They’re your business. He smiles and ducks down into his car. Connie turns to Rita.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: You can speak to ‘em. It’s your bloody fault. She crosses to the car, too. And we see she is hiding a smile, too. She clambers into the car. On Rita. Worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls are all hard at work when the hooter sounds. Brenda and Eileen start to make themselves decent but then stop when they see who it is: Rita, standing on a bench, looking out over them. Connie is beside her, at ground level. A beat. Rita hesitates, glances to Connie, then looks back again. She shouts:

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Everybody out! A huge roar and the women push to the exit. EXT. WESTMINSTER — DAY 30 Big Ben booms out and a new day dawns. INT. BARBARA CASTLE’S WESTMINSTER OFFICES - DAY 31 Another pair of bare feet, the stockinged soles of which scratch an itch beneath a large desk. Then, we see a sign on the desk: SECRETARY OF STATE FOR EMPLOYMENT AND PRODUCTIVITY and behind it, the petite figure of a woman with flame red hair, pouring over a huge pile of manila files.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Now, I realise this is my first day in the job...And it may be that I’m missing something here- She speaks in a thick Lancashire accent which has poshed up over the years. She looks up and stares at two clean cut men in their twenties, her undersecretaries, who sit opposite. Then she stands and walks from behind her desk. She paces the room.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But what I do know, is that when we were elected two years ago, it was on a wave of optimism, that the Labour Party would utilise it’s close relationship with the Unions to develop manufacturing industry; to make it better serve the employer and the employee The man glance at each other uncertainly.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSECRETARY
dialogues.text: I think that was part of the manifesto-

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: It was, trust me. Her tone is entirely rhetorical. She stares at the men. Then she looks even more censorious-

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what exactly have you been doing? Since nineteen sixty six?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Two years! This department has had two years to make a difference. Yet- (stops herself) Well... shall we see what’s been achieved in the last twelve months? She goes back to her desk; checks notes-—

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 26,000 strikes. In the United Kingdom. With 5 million working days lost as a result. Unions and management barely speaking to each other. Productivity levels through the floor and our balance of payments the wrong side of catastrophic... it’s hardly the stuff to set champagne corks popping, is it? She stops; gathers herself.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS
dialogues.text: 32 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 26aA

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: However, it is my intention to reverse this trend... I have my own ideas as how that might be achieved. But now I’d like to hear your thoughts... The men glance at each other.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t all shout at once... (looks them up and down) Gentlemen. INT. CONNIE’S HOUSE - DAY 32 The front room of a small terrace; simpler and less plush than Rita’s home. George sits in an armchair by the fire. He looks pale. The newspaper is folded on his lap. He blinks, a pronounced tic. And then Connie hurries in from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Here you go- She carries a fizzy glass of something. She holds it out to him.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Down in one- He takes it. But then he doesn’t drink it. He places it on a small table beside him and sits back, picking up the paper as if she isn’t there.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You gotta drink it, George... He looks at her. Surprised. Zones in again.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He downs it; winces.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: It’s the latest stuff, that. It's...He...reckons you'll really notice a difference. They stare at each other. He manages a smile. Then-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You gotta go, have you? She holds his gaze and forces a beaming smile.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: It’s important. (grabs her jacket) You know where I’1l be... (turns) Just don’t you be late. She smiles, determined. He nods, unconvincingly. Then she’s off. George watches the closed door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great mob of the striking women are gathered by the locked River Plant gates. Several of them wave placards and banners, excited, calling out to the many men who are cycling into the main plant-

dialogues.speaker: BLOKE
dialogues.text: Up the strikers...Specially you Brenda-

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: (flicking vees) You wish!

dialogues.speaker: BLOKE TWO
dialogues.text: Gaaaaarn...give ‘em what for- Rita smiles at Eddie who grins and winks as he sails by on his bike.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Get stuck in, girls! Eileen spots Dave as he cycles in. She waves proudly. Sandra, jiggling a banner, shouts out-

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: We want respect! Rita and Brenda turn to Sandra. She wears tight slacks, a tight blouse and is heavily made up.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: What you done to your eyes?

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: They’re amazin’, aren't they? Me best friend showed me how.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: This is a demonstration, you know, Sandra-

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: And I’m demonstratin’... (conspiratorially) There’s scouts everywhere! That’s how Twiggy got discovered. Just walkin’ down the street-

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Up West, you dozy sod. Not Dagenham- Another whistle of support. Connie leans in to Rita.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I can’t believe we done this...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Least they know we’re serious now. And we ain’t quite as helpless as everyone seems to think we are. Rita looks proudly across at the girls-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hopkins is uneasy. He walks through the empty River Plant and looks at all the idle machines. EXT. FORD HEADQUARTERS, MICHIGAN —- MORNING 35 The sun beats down on one of the Great Lakes. Then we see a gleaming building, sitting in a wide, open, vista. In front of the building, glinting in the brightness is a sign: FORD MOTOR COMPANY, USA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Air conditioning hums. In a light and airy space, a man in his mid forties drops food into a huge aquarium whilst speaking on the ‘phone.

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: Peter, Bobby here...What can I do for you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hopkins sits in his cramped and dingy office, an old electric fan dinging on a filing cabinet behind him.

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: We've got another dispute, I’m afraid- INT. FORD HEADQUARTERS, MICHIGAN —- MORNING 38

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: Another one? Who is it this week? He turns from the tank. That is new. EXT. RIVER PLANT — AFTERNOON 39 Baby Come Back by The Equals blasts from a transistor radio around which several of the girls dance. A crate of beer lies on the floor. Deck chairs have now been found, also, and many of the women sit in them, eating ice cream wafers which Eileen dispenses from a large box. A bin wagon passes and the driver slows, leans out-

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: It’s a lot more fun on your picket than ours usually are. I might join you later.

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: It’s women only, love. The girls laugh, the bin waggon pips and accelerates away, swerving past a van which pulls up beside the women. Written on the van’s side is: A.A. Horovitz Greengrocer. The door opens and Brenda gets out. She has several brown paper bags in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Tea’s up! Bananas, apples, pears! The girls rush over to help themselves. Then from the van steps Mr Horovitz, about twenty five and VERY good looking. He also looks, however, exhausted. He removes Brenda’s bike from the back of the van and places it on the side. Brenda waves to him.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks for the ride, Arthur! He nods, embarrassed, clambers in and zooms off. The girls are open mouthed.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Brenda!...You never-

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Why? He’s gorgeous...And just as I was leavin’ with the fruit, he goes: “I believe all the workers of the world should unite.” And I thought to meself, I can help you with that one straight away, mate. She bites an apple and sits. Suddenly Connie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, much as I'd like to hang around, discussin’ solidarity for another eight hours...Me date’s here- George crosses the road. He looks immaculate, wearing a suit, his hair neatly Brycleemed. A couple of whistles as he stops. He smiles. But he still looks slightly hollow eyed.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Don’t you scrub up nice...What’s goin’ on?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (thrilled) You made it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It’s our anniversary...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What? A chorus of the girls calling out Connie’s name, cooing and clapping.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you say something-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I didn’t wanna make a fuss... (brightening) So, say “up yours” to the management from me, will you?! We’re off. She leaves to shouts of ‘bye’ and ‘enjoy yourselves’.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Right. Who’s for a game of pontoon?- She produces cards. Just as there is an immense rumble of thunder. Moans from the girls.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: I knew it was too good to last-

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: It’ll be fine- And the rain comes. Squeals from the girls as they rush about and gather up stuff.

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: What we gonna do? Pubs aren’t open- Rita, gathering placards, looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I dunno...We have done a full day-

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: And I promised me mum I'd cook tea.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (grinning) Sod it! We registered the protest...Hooter’s blowin’ The girls cheer. The whole group runs around, packing, shouting hurried good byes and dispersing.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Hey and Rita!- (Rita looks round) Well done! (Rita frowns) Was your gob got us here, wannit? Brenda leaves. Beat. Rita smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert's POV as he watches Rita struggling with the placards, he bangs on the window to get her attention, she comes over to the doorway of the café.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Albert-

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Just been round your house. He wipes his face with his hanky. Rita watches him.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Cause I thought you’d’a gone home ages ago...I’m lucky if I can get the lads to hold out the full hour-

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 32
dialogues.text: Albert notices the placards and smiles. He then looks to Rita who stares at him expectantly:

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh...I wanted a quick chat, was all... (indicates cafe) Fancy a cuppa?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I can’t. Sorry...I told Graham I’d meet him from school.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (checks time) You got twenty minutes ‘fore they tip out, ain’t you? She frowns; that’s rather insistent. He looks up from his watch, meeting her gaze. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m buyin’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita stares as Albert spoons three sugars into his tea. He stirs and looks at her. She waits, a little edgy. Then he adds one more. She makes to speak- He stirs again-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Albert, come on! Cough it up! He looks her in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Alright...You won’t win.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: This battle...You’re gonna lose-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: But...we got a case. You said so. We-

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Oh, don’t get us wrong. You might get Ford to back down over the gradin’ thing but...I’m talkin’ big picture. And in that case, you ain’t even in the frame-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (irritated) What do you mean we’re not-—

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: -'Cause this dispute’s got nothin’ to do with what skill level you are! Ford’s decided to give you less money ‘cause they can...They’re allowed to pay women a lower wage than men. She stares at him. ALBERT (CONT’D) And not just Ford neither. The whole country, Rita. Women gettin’ less...because they’re women... She stares at him. She’s already there but daren’t say it. He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’1l always come second, you’1ll always be dependent, you'll always be fightin’ for the scraps from the top table as long as-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: -we ain’t got equal pay...

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Oh, Rita, if you knew how thick most of the blokes I deal with are... She stares. It makes sense. But she’s scared. She looks away. A second. She looks back, a new thought in her head

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Why? Why you bothered about us gettin’ the same as the men? He stares; knows Rita will accept only the whole truth. He smiles fondly.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I got brought up by me mum...Me and me brothers. Me dad cleared off when we were nippers, SO... (nods ) She worked all her life at Ranley and Coopers. Ball bearin’s...She paid aunt Lilly for lookin’ after us durin’ the day and... He stares, forcing back the emotion. Then to Rita:

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -..it was hard. Especially cause she got paid less than half what the blokes in the factory was gettin’. For doin’ the same work...But there was never any question it could be different...Not for her. (smiles, fondly at Rita) You remind me of her, actually, Rita...You got heart and...brains and- (frowns ) -and someone has to stop those exploitin’ bastards from gettin’ away with what they been doin’ for years! He looks back, his eyes filmed with water.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you can. You can. If you make your battle focus on the right target. Rita stares, suddenly energised. But she’s scared, too.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What about Connie? She’s Shop Steward. We voted for her-

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: And she’s magnificent, Rita! At organizin’. And implementin’. But this needs...a leader. To inspire the girls. To make the issues clear. And that ain’t her. Not at the moment-— (Rita makes to speak) And she knows it. ‘Cause I’ve already spoke to her. (Rita is shocked) And she’s more than happy to let you have a go...More than. (touches her arm reassuringly) Look...Don’t say nothin’ now. It’s a big thing, I know that. Just...sleep on it, will you? And let me know tomorrow... (smiles, nods) Here. I’1l take them. Least I can do. He picks up the placards and goes. Rita watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita glances at her watch as she hurries towards the school. A group of the mothers wait. All under umbrellas. Rita hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: LISA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Do you want to wait in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns. A brand new Ford escort is parked by the kerb, and LISA is poking her head out of the driver’s side window. Rita recognises her immediately.

dialogues.speaker: LISA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have met. In the corridor outside Mr Clarke’s class. (Rita stares. Lisa shoves open the passenger door) Please- Rita glances at the other mothers and suddenly feels a surge of opportunity. With her nose in the air, she hurries over and climbs in. INT. CAR -— DAY 43 Rita arranges herself.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I’m drippin’...

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: It's fine. Really...I’ve been hoping to bump into you for a day or two actually. (Rita stiffens) I wondered if you’d care to sign a letter...? To the headmaster. I’m making a formal complaint; about Mr Clarke’s use of the cane-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: He seems to think my son’s-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You mean...You were there for the same reason as me?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Yes...He was...indiscreet enough to mention why you’d been in...I think he was suggesting something hormonal was happening about the school- (bitter) We should all calm down a bit.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: -He just fobbed me off. He...I mean...I’d got it all worked out in me head; what I was gonna say only-

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Oh, you don’t talk to Mr Clarke. You listen... (scoffs) He’s a bully...That’s why he beats them all-

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 36
dialogues.text: Lisa stops. Rita stares at her impassioned face. And relief floods her body.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You got a pen, then? Lisa passes across the letter and pen. Rita signs. Hands everything back.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -That first time, when I saw you... (Lisa frowns, confused) You’re bein’ polite, not mentionin’ it, I know you are, only...I was upset. As I say and...I never use that sort of language normally.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Don’t you? I called Mr Clarke a complete cock... Rita is stunned; Lisa smiles. Children are now pouring out of the school.

dialogues.speaker: LISA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here they are... Lisa gets out. Rita, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa has an umbrella which she erects and then she moves over to Rita who stands beside her, beneath it. Rita glances across and suddenly, emboldened-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: That dress-— (Lisa turns, frowns) I seen it. In Vogue...It really suits you.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Thank you...It’s Biba. A second. Lisa looks back to the children. Rita does too. And her chest swells ever so slightly. INT. RITA’S HOUSE - DAY 45 Rita places a mug of tea on a bedside table. Eddie is dozing but now he opens one eye. Rita slips back into bed, her red, nylon nightie crackling, and props herself up against the headboard.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Ta, love... (frowns ) What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Six-

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: We got another half an hour-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (distracted) Yeah. Sorry. I was awake anyway, SO... She trails off. A beat. He turns on his side.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Well, now you are...Shame to waste an opportunity-— He nibbles her hip. She giggles.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Eddie! He pulls himself up her body and kisses her neck. She’s not really in the mood, though.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: What?...What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Nothin’...I’m...I got stuff on me mind... (she turns; dare she?) Which...I didn’t say nothin’ about last night ‘cause I wanted to get straight in me own head first-

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Get what straight? She looks at him for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I’ve decided to get a bit more involved. In the dispute.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: What dispute? It’s happened...it was yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Yeah, but...it ain’t settled yet, is it?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: No, I know but...you’ve made your gesture. That’s all I mean-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: It wasn’t a gesture. It was a...strike...to get somethin’!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Fine...It’s not worth rowin’ over, is it? He smiles. Then kisses her shoulder several times.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got my support, Rita. You know that. Whatever you wanna do.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Good. Thank you... (he kisses her again) You’re not just sayin’ that, are you?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (still kissing) Hmmm? —

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: ‘Cause you got an ulterior motive! He finally straightens and looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: What’s that mean? She stares at his honest, open face. She grins.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I‘1l show you. She kisses him and they slide down the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita places her bike in the rack. She smiles as Brenda dismounts, too. But then, both stare open mouthed as Sandra arrives - in a pair of tiny shorts and a blouse tied just below the bust. Sandra struggles to get her leg over the bike seat.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Bloody hell Sandra, I think you’ve had a bit’ve shrinkage in the wash-

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: They’re hot pants. They’re Mary Quant’s-—

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Well you should give ‘em back to her. They look fuckin’ painful-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I think they look nice. Long as you can breathe-

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Course, I can...And it’s what Brenda said, innit: it ain’t Knightsbridge...Dagenham. So if you're gonna get spotted, you have to stand out that bit more. Well, I am doin’... She walks off. Brenda watches her, then looks to Rita.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Come on... She sets off after Sandra but just as suddenly stops and turns back.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wannit great, though? Yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (surprised) Bein’ on strike?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Chance to be different...Was lovely. (smiles) Felt like it all night.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Met the veg man, got blind drunk, then went back to his place.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (confused) But-—

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Oh, it was different, Rita... (winks ) Just ask him.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 39A
dialogues.text: She happily wanders in. Rita scoffs and follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita, a hint of a smile still on her face, walks towards the factory floor, pulling her overalls around her waist as she goes.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 40
dialogues.text: BUT then she stops. The notice board is directly ahead. On it, MACHINIST rates of pay: MEN: £19 7s 6d WOMEN: £13 4s 2d Rita stares. She looks determined. Then uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita walks onto the floor. She stares at Connie’s space: still unoccupied. She begins to thread up her machine. Then she grabs some cuttings. And finally Connie rushes in-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I’m here! Just...Christ- She grabs her bowl and places it on the floor. Then she pulls her overalls down and she stops - as she sees Rita staring at her.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Connie, listen. I-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (shaking head) Rita-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: No! I have to say it! For me! (stares at Connie) If I was to get involved with Albert, Con, it’s only cause...I got a gob on me...You’re the heart beat of this place. You always will be. Connie smiles, fondly. Then:

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Rita...Look at me. All at six’s and seven’s...Again- (quietly) I got enough on me plate at the moment, without takin’ on the whole of British Industry... (nods ) You can do it. And you should. Rita stares at Connie; makes to speak. But the hooter sounds and the machines start up. The women smile and get down to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita finishes an item, then notices Sandra, tongue out, carefully completing a piece. She is pleased. Then the hooter goes and the girls look across, on the point of getting dressed. But it is Brian, so they simply continue. He looks frustrated. Then scared; as he realises he must enter anyway. This he does and at every bench the women jiggle their bits, wolf whistle and generally make life hell for him.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Hello Brian...That a cotton bob you got in your pocket?...Or is it an hard on? He reaches into a sack he is carrying and shoves a letter straight at Brenda. She frowns but soon all the girls have them. Rita opens her envelope and reads. She looks furious and then catches Connie’s eye. A second and Rita marches off. As she arrives at the door, Albert appears, in his Ford overalls, coming for her decision. She marches past him, thunder on her face, glancing once at him as she strides on. He grins.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (to himself) That a yes, then? And then, he sets off after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monty Taylor, in his suit and Union badge, stares at the letter. Albert is by his side. They are surrounded by the girls.

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: Ignore it.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Ignore it?

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: Standard issue. Day after a walk out.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Have you seen the language? (Eileen and Brenda nod) "Your flagrant and aggressive disregard for the existing complaints procedure”...Tone of that-

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: They don’t mean it.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS
dialogues.text: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 41aA

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: So why they sayin’ it...?

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: ‘Cause...that’s how we’ve always done it. All the other strikes. It’s like the rules—

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Oh, no! (snatches letter back) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We’re not playin’ that game...We ain’t your men, remember. We’re us. And we won't be addressed in this manner. (Cheer of agreement. Rita stares at the girls) All those in favour of not only maintainin’ but increasin’ our current industrial action by goin’ to an immediate all out stoppage until an equal pay settlement is reached-

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: What? Monty has spoken for them all. Mutterings of “equal pay?” are heard everywhere. Rita turns to the girls:

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Well, why not? (stares at the trusting faces of the girls) That’s what this dispute is really about, innit?! Rita suddenly points to the lad seen earlier. He sweeps out the canteen now.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They’ve put us on the same rate as Brushin’ Brian! The lowest rate in the whole factory...despite the fact that we have got considerable skill. (A few mumbled “trues”) And there’s only one possible reason for that...‘Cause we’re women, and in the work place women get paid less than men- no matter what skill they got! (More support. Agreement. Shouts now.) Which is why we gotta demand that from now on, there’s a level playin’ field and rates of pay which reflect the job you do, not whether you’ve got a dick or not- (cheers of support) This strike is about one thing and one thing only: Fairness! (To Monty; points) Equal pay or nothin’! (huge cheer; Rita turns back to the women) All those in favour? (every hand goes up) Everybody out!!!!

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 43
dialogues.text: Another cheer and Rita walks to the exit, stopping by the door as a wave of the girls passes her and empties the building. Monty looks panicked and glares at Albert. Albert shrugs with a wry smile.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Nothin’ to do with me. The women sweep out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hopkins looks stunned. He stands beside a window held open by a block of wood.

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: An all out stoppage?! Monty fidgets before Hopkins’ desk.

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: Also...The specifics of the strike...It’s widened out a bit-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hopkins appears in his doorway. He is ashen. He looks at his secretary, then he mutters to himself:

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: Christ... INT. FORD HEADQUARTER’S, MICHIGAN - MORNING 54 Tooley listens on the phone. He is deadpan.

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
dialogues.text: Fuckin’ Ada! CLIVE BARTHOLOMEW, sixty, bearded, stares at Monty. Another middle aged man, ROGERS, also glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 44
dialogues.text: BARTHOLOMEW (CONT’D) Equal pay! What were you thinkin’, Monty?

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: It wasn’t me...It was Albert. He...He went behind me back-

dialogues.speaker: ROGERS
dialogues.text: Really-

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: He’s a loose canon. He- (grasping at straws) I got him with me...You wanna haul someone over the coals, he’s your man; the bloody trouble maker. A beat. Bartholomew and Rogers exchange a glance. Then Bartholomew nods to Monty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert, still in Ford overalls, sits on a chair waiting. Monty enters. He looks at Albert and sighs theatrically.

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: I tried to protect you Albert. But you are gonna get such a fuckin’ bollockin’... Albert considers Monty and nods. He stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert sits on another chair in the middle of the room. Bartholomew paces up and down for a moment. Then-

dialogues.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
dialogues.text: This is awkward, Albert, you know that, don’t you? It jeopardises a whole...raft of other negotiations the unions already at loggerheads with the management over-

dialogues.speaker: ROGERS
dialogues.text: Not to mention protocol. There’s ways of goin’ on strike. Right ways and wrong ways-

dialogues.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
dialogues.text: Look...Comrade...Basically, you encouragin’ these women...to get all militant-

dialogues.speaker: ROGERS
dialogues.text: -shifts the resources away from the blokes...who let’s be straight, are the ones at the coal face-

dialogues.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
dialogues.text: We ain’t unsympathetic! But...as a union...we have to remember who comes first...The Communist Party. And Marx himself said: “Men make their own history.” That’s men, Albert! Monty sighs. He did warn Albert. Albert smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Didn't he also say: “progress can be measured by the social position of the female sex”...Or was that a different Marx? Was that Groucho? Bartholomew makes to respond but Albert stands: his turn now.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Equal pay! Across the board! You tellin’ me that ain’t worth fightin’ for? Course it is! And you know it! Only cause’ve all the in-fightin’ and the prejudice and the sixteen other unions down at Ford all lookin’ after their own little patch, you ain’t even tried, have you? Well, you listen to me. This...Rita...she’s got a bigger set of balls than the three of you put together and she ain't scared of layin’ ‘em on the line neither, so I, for one, am gonna help her and if you are, what you say you are, an organisation pledged to support its members - which everyone of them girls most definitely is - then you'll get off your fat, lazy arses and you'll help her, too! Good fuckin’ evenin! He storms out of the room. Rogers looks to Bartholomew. They’re fucked. A beat. They turn on Monty, furious. He cowers. MUSIC STARTS: BORN TO BE WILD - STEPPENWOLF: "Get your motor runnin’...”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rally in front of the Town Hall before about fifty people. Albert is on the platform with various other officials. A banner reads A FAIR DAYS PAY FOR A FAIR DAYS WORK. Rita is there, too. Albert finishes speaking and Rita nervously steps forward. A long pause. And then Rita sees Connie, Brenda and the girls. She begins-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (faltering) I...work at Ford...As a machinist and...I’m here to put our point of view. About what’s goin’ on and how, it ain’t fair. And also, how it’s part of somethin’ bigger...much bigger...which is equal pay... She continues. A man in a threadbare coat, a camera around his neck, takes out a notebook and starts writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita addresses a crowd of onlookers. Thirty or so girls are gathered around her, including Connie and Sandra who hold up a banner proclaiming: SUPPORT THE FORD MACHINISTS. Passing are a group of West Ham fans on the way to a match with scarves and rattles. Several stop and listen. Rita sounds much smoother.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: ‘Cause basically, Ford’s done what they have, awarded us a pay cut, ‘cause they think no-one’1ll really notice, because we’re women. And women’s pay has always been less than men’s... MORE HEADLINES: PETTICOAT REBELLION GROWS etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon and Frank arrive at the River Plant’s deserted warehouse area on the forklift. They swing open two massive doors. Inside, the store is packed with thousands of finished headrests, seat covers and door trim. Both men look at each other ruefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita addresses a mass of workers. She is noticeably more confident and slicker.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: And that’s a tactic, not just the Ford Management, but all managements have exploited, year after year: basin’ huge profits on a wage system which is as corrupt as it is unchallenged-

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 47
dialogues.text: A couple of men glance at each other and nod; fair point. HEADLINE: FORD STRIKERS LEAD WOMEN’S RIGHTS MOVE

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Which begs the question, why? Why is it like that? And the answer is, us! Because we've never said no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the more modern main plant, we see Albert, then Dave who is holding up a copy of the Dagenham and Redbridge Echo. BANNER HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT DENY CRISIS. Then we hear Rita’s voice, gliding, over the picture.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: We've meekly stepped forwards, despite what we've seen with our mothers and our grandmothers and we’ve taken our pay packets and we’ve tugged our forelocks and we’ve said “thank you very much.” Well, no more! The time has come for all women to say: Enough! We do not accept this! We hear applause. And see Eddie, smiling bashfully, as a picture of Rita, campaigning, is pointed out to him, beneath the banner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The applause fades as Rita steps down from the platform. She is immediately approached by several reporters and other union officials.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Rita... She turns. Albert indicates a young man who stands away from the crush. ALBERT (CONT’D) There's a bloke here from The Times. Rita tries not to react. MUSIC ENDS EXT. TOOLEY’S OFFICE - DAY 64 A copy of The Times lies on the polished desk in Tooley’s office. Tooley sits on one side of the desk and on the other is a man with a leathery face and buzz cut hair. Both men stare at a plastic box in the middle of the desk. It is perforated with dark holes and has a thick power cord running from it. Suddenly, from the box, a silky smooth woman's voice emanates

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS
dialogues.text: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 47aA

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Hardey is ready to speak now gentlemen. Thank you so much for waiting. Tooley and Kronnfeld glance at each other. A click. But then nothing. Kronnfeld loses his nerve and leans forward to speak. He’s beaten to it-

dialogues.speaker: HARDEY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I though your boy said he could handle this? Kronnfeld stiffens. JEB HARDEY, sixty, boss of Ford America, has a gruff, blue collar voice.

dialogues.speaker: HARDEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And do we even know what we’re dealing with here? Socialist Workers Party; Workers Revolutionary Party; Revolutionary Communist Party?... Who's she with? Kronnfeld glances quickly at the impassive Tooley and then down, dry mouthed, to an open file on his desk; it is the duplicate of the one before Tooley. A picture of Rita is uppermost on both. Kronnfeld takes a breath and does his best.

dialogues.speaker: KRONNFELD
dialogues.text: We don’t think she’s with anyone, Sir. We don’t even think she’s a communist. She’s looks like she’s-

dialogues.speaker: HARDEY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -She looks like Rita Heyworth, goddamit, I don’t care! I wanna know why she’s acting like this! Kronnfeld sits back, wide eyed. He’s done. He’s given it his best shot. Tooley, unimpressed by Kronnfeld’s disintegration, leans closer to the communications box-

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: The fact is, sir... she hasn’t got a background in politics, in or outside the union... her husband’s a moderate, so... we think she’s just got a beef-

dialogues.speaker: HARDEY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A beef! That’s what she’s got? Bobby, if this woman gets what she wants and Ford Motors is forced to introduce equal pay for men and women in the UK... we’ll end up havin’ to do it right across the world! (threatening) Do you understand that?

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS
dialogues.text: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 47aB

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HARDEY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So deal with it! Now! A click. Beat. Kronnfeld looks like a man who has been involved in a road accident. But, then he sighs relief as he turns to Tooley

dialogues.speaker: KRONNFELD
dialogues.text: I guess you'll be getting the next flight outta here Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Castle sighs, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Prime Minister...I’m not sure you quite appreciate the urgency of the situation... as of 5pm yesterday there were 405 strikes in progress nationally... Harold Wilson turns.
