He has a dog on a lead. Mrs Castle looks at it distastefully. Wilson considers Mrs Castle and then walks on. She follows, struggling, as her heels sink into the grass. Two of her undersecretaries follow her. She stops suddenly. Because Wilson has stopped. Because the dog is taking a crap. He looks at it fondly. Mrs Castle winces; would say more. But Wilson is delighted by the distraction.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD WILSON
dialogues.text: It's always white when he goes to the toilet. Yet he never eats anything white. (Mrs Castle is stunned) Mary gives him the odd fruit gum-

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Prime Minister! He hears her aggrieved tone; looks across, awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD WILSON
dialogues.text: I’m not saying I won't legislate. Just- The dog now trots on. Wilson gladly follows. And Mrs. Castle, too! She will not be deflected-

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: What? We’ve talked about this a hundred times... Until you introduce new bills, which give me the power to regulate the Unions, I cannot get the country back to work-—

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD WILSON
dialogues.text: I understand that... (she looks hopeful) But we need to tread carefully; draw the unions in- Her heart sinks. The Undersecretary leans in.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSECRETARY
dialogues.text: We have to acknowledge that without the unions there would be no Labour Party- She stops; so does he.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Young man! I was a member of the Trades Union Movement while you were still at your Mother’s breast... so unless you have something to add which goes beyond the blindingly obvious, I'd prefer it if you kept quiet! He slinks off. Mrs Castle totters on, catching up with Wilson. She tries a different tone.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Harold- He looks down. She has put her hand on his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -You asked me to do this job; you appointed me-

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD WILSON
dialogues.text: You’re the best man in my cabinet, Barbara, I often say that- He laughs nervously. But his joke hasn't deflected her. She’s staring at him. ALL woman.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: I can’t do it without you, Harold- Wilson finally turns away, graps a stick at throws it for the dog.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need you to... Wilson stops dead. Then, from a dry throat, Wilson croaks

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD WILSON
dialogues.text: Jack Scamp! (her face falls) He’s your man. Any... impasse... get Jack in. Sits them all round a table; beer and pork pie. Straight talking negotiation... (nods ) He’s the way forward. Mrs Castle takes a deep breath and nods. Seduction failed, she’s back in war mode.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Beer and pork pie... Might not do for the latest one. Down at Ford. (Wilson frowns) 187 Machinists. All women... Perhaps get a finger buffet in, eh? She turns, starts to walk, sinks, takes of her shoes then strides back across the lawn, thunderous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A city gent, in suit and bowler, stands silently with many other commuters on their regular run into the City. He looks uneasy. And as we pass along his carriage, we see the girls crushed at its far end, chatting excitedly, their protest paraphernalia causing considerable disruption. The city gent looks distastefully away. But then he leaps and his hand goes to his backside. Someone has pinched his arse. Then we see Brenda, close by. She smiles sweetly. EXT. LONDON TUBE -—- DAY 67A The girls emerge from the tube, blinking into the bright sunlight. They are gossiping madly, excited and some, a little overawed.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Come on, then, girls! Get yourselves organised!

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Anyone fancy a Wimpy?...I’m starvin’- Rita turns, distracted-

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: We ain’t got time to see the sites, have we?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: No, we have not! Now Sandra appears in tiny shorts and a skimpy top. She looks round, urgently.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Where’s all the press, then?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: We ain’t there yet!

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: We gotta get to parliament first, you silly sod-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (frustrated) Exactly!

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: So?...Which way is it?

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 51A
dialogues.text: Rita looks round. Then she sighs, having to come clean-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (to girls) I think it’s this way, isn’t it? The girls all look in different directions. Clearly no one knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls arrive on a small lawned area outside the Houses of Parliament.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Alright, ladies! This is a good spot. Form up! They put down their bags and begin unfurling the banners.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 52
dialogues.text: INT. BARBARA CASTLE’S WESTMINSTER OFFICES - DAY 69 Mrs Castle sighs. She is leafing through more reports of industrial unrest. Then she becomes aware of the pips outside-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls are gathered with their banners. A car toots... and another. The girls wave. Men shout encouragement. A driver leans from the cab of a passing van and calls across.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Here, I finish work at four. Give us a call! His mate laughs. The girls wave back, blithely. More people react and the girls shout back, giddy with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: It’s unbelievable... I never thought we’d get this backing- More pips and Rita frowns. She looks up, at the banner she holds. A moment.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Girls...I think we’re not entirely unfurled. All of them look up to the banner. It says: WE WANT SEX INT. BARBARA CASTLE’S WHITEHALL OFFICES - DAY 71 Mrs Castle looks out of her window. Sees the banner.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: I know the feeling. She walks back to her stressful work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside we see Connie help Rita frantically untwist the banner. WE WANT SEX EQUALITY is revealed. Rita, flustered, gestures for the girls to re-group. Most are giggling. Reporters and photographers are approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the laughter, Sandra is suddenly aware that photographers are taking pictures. She skips over to them. Rita turns to the approaching press.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Go on, Rita! Tell ‘em how it is!- But Rita is already stepping forward to meet the advance as Sandra poses, off to one side. The others stand and watch as Rita is engulfed by reporters. A man approaches Brenda. He is scruffy, bearded. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Hello. Brenda looks at him. She’s never seen anyone like him before.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Hello. He hands her a leaflet from a pile he is holding. She looks at it. It’s about a political rally. When she looks back up he is gone. The photographers finally finish taking pictures of Sandra, she comes over.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: It's quite interesting, politics. When you get down to it.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: What makes this strike different- -is that it’s not about a specific pay settlement-

dialogues.speaker: TALKS TO CAMERA NOW-
dialogues.text: REPORTER (CONT’D) -but the whole issue of sex discrimination-

dialogues.speaker: ARE SHOVED INTO HER FACE.
dialogues.text: A cheer in the background. And ON SCREEN we see- REPORTER (CONT’D) How long are the girls prepared to stay out?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER TWO
dialogues.text: It must be starting to bite now-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: As long as it takes-

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER TWO
dialogues.text: Does your husband support you in all this? Another cheer in the background.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: He has to!

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: He...supports me...We always support the men when they come out.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: What about the other Ford women; in Liverpool? Are they behind you?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: They will be. Several reporters call out. One persists.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER THREE
dialogues.text: Does it bother you you’ve been described as a Revlon Revolutionary?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER THREE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have they been in touch? About doing some modelling work for them. Laughter from the reporters. Rita smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I prefer to concentrate on the issues of the strike-

dialogues.speaker: TV NEWSCASTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -After the March protests in Grosvenor Square, this months student riots in Paris- TV PICTURE IS REPLACED BY A TEST MATCH.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ha! Ain’t that somethin’?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave and Eddie turn from the TV, pints in hand.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. She’s doin’ alright.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: And she mentioned you...On the television... (jabs finger at Eddie) You gotta smart woman there, Eddie. Eddie nods, uneasily. Then smiles. He glances at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I gotta get goin’-

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Already?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I know...I gotta fetch the kids... (Dave frowns) Rita reckons they won’t be back ‘til gone six, so...I need to get ‘em sorted. He smiles ruefully at Dave and downs his pint.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You tell her to get her finger out. When you see her.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS
dialogues.text: 55 And for the first time we notice George, sitting on a stool by the bar. He stares at his half of mild, not looking at Dave or Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gone on long enough now.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (laughing) I don’t think they're deliberately draggin’ it out, George-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's alright for you and him. Two wages in the house. I’ve got me war pension and I’ve got what she earns. That’s it...I can’t afford a bastard strike.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I know that...And they’1l settle it; soon as they can. George says nothing more. Eddie nods and goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A coach pulls up outside a factory gate. On it is 74 written: FORD, HALEWOOD. Rita gets off. Several of the girls follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 75 Rita stands on a soap box outside the main factory. She is sweating, passionate, addressing a crowd of women.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: -You’re doin’ the same work for Ford, here in Liverpool, that we’re doin’ for ‘em down in Dagenham. So you know that our job is skilled...But I’m askin’ you to think beyond that...I’m askin’ you to strike now for all women, not just machinists, until every one of us gets fairness and is entitled to the same pay as men!...Will all those in favour, put their hands in the air now, please- They do. Rita beams, delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids sit at the dining room table. Smoke spills from the kitchen. They glance at each other. Look slightly worried. INT. RITA’S HOUSE, KITCHEN - EARLY EVENING 77 The kitchen is a mess as Eddie, sweat dripping from his nose, tries to fry a piece of liver. A huge flame leaps up from under the pan as spitting oil hits the gas. Eddie leaps back, cursing, then goes back to the food, his jaw tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie drops newspaper wrapped fish and chips onto Sharon's plate. Sharon glances at Graham. She is struggling not to snigger as she undoes the package and takes a chip. Graham laughs out loud as he receives his bundle of food. Eddie looks thoroughly pissed off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls drive back from Halewood. Rita, sitting at the front, with Connie beside her, glances out over burnished countryside, a low red sun throbbing in the sky. Across the aisle, also at the front, Sandra has a transistor radio on her lap, a single ear piece in. She starts to sing, quietly as she looks out of the window-

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Once upon a time, there was a tavern, where we used to raise a glass or two- (Brenda, next to her, looks across) Remember how we laughed away the hours- Brenda starts to sing. And then Connie joins in.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA, CONNIE
dialogues.text: Think of all the great things we would do- Rita sings. And others, too. Sandra realises, then, smiling, continues in full voice with the rest:

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Those were the days, my friend, We thought they'd never end, We'd sing and dance forever and a day- (Rita laughs) We'd live the life we'd choose, We'd fight and never lose, For we were young and sure to have our way-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus slips through the warm, summer night-

dialogues.speaker: ALL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: La La La La La La-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hopkins opens his front door and approaches Tooley, who is getting out of a taxi.

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: Welcome. How was your flight?

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: Long.

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry to drag you over.

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: They're taking this very seriously. Right at the top.

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: Come in. My wife’s cooking dinner... They walk into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hopkins passes into a modern, late sixties, detached house. Tooley follows.

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: Really, I don’t want to be any trouble.

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: Honestly...Least I can do...Let me take your coat. Hopkins wife appears in a pinny. Lisa. HOPKINS (CONT’D) Lisa...This is Robert Tooley-

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: Delighted to meet you at last.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Likewise. They shake. Then Hopkins hands Tooley’s coat to Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: I was saying to Peter; I’m quite happy to eat later; at the hotel-

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: Nonsense! She loves to cook. (glances at Lisa) Don’t you?..Just relax. Have a drink. I’11 run you back when we’re finished. Hopkins passes his coat to Lisa too and ushers Tooley through into the sitting room. Lisa looks at the coats and then hangs them up. INT. RITA’S HOUSE - NIGHT 83 Rita walks into the house, excited. The place is chaotic but it seems hardly to register as she smiles, seeing Eddie arriving at the foot of the stairs. He bends stiffly to pick up some clothes, then straightens and spots her. She beams.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Go alright, then?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I slaughtered ‘em! Every single one come out!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Well done. He moves into the kitchen and starts to collect the plates. She follows.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: It was incredible though, Eddie! To start with. A load of ‘em said, while they was happy to support their fellow machinists...union solidarity and all that...they didn’t actually agree with equal pay as a principal. Men deserved more...Can you believe that? He looks at her; her ebullience. And suddenly feels troubled. But he manages a smile.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’‘1l go and check on the kids. Give ‘ema quick kiss. She pecks him on the cheek and goes. He stares at the cluttered table. His effort. Anger swells.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I managed alright. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa clears away. Bottles of beer sit on the table.

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: Can you bring some brandy glasses back in with you? She nods and smiles. Then turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: Lisa...You must have a quite head on your shoulders...Peter tells me you read history. At Cambridge-

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Yeah- She nods, proudly but then suddenly becomes aware of the plates in her hand. She puts them on the sideboard.

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: So whadda you make of our little problem; over at the factory? (nods to Peter) Think maybe he’s a bit too much velvet glove and not enough iron fist? She seems uncertain, then shrugs, relaxing.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I don’t actually. Just the opposite. Look at Vauxhall. They don’t appear to have any problem with the unions and that seems to me because General Motors have a much more collaborative approach to Management. Whereas at Ford, you seem only to deal with the unions because you have to...You tolerate them. And as a result they’re much more entrenched and aggressive in the way that they deal with you. Tooley looks at her. Then he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: That’s a very...progressive point of view, Lisa. (turns to alarmed Hopkins) Isn't it? He stares at Hopkins, his expression at once benign but threatening. Hopkins hesitates, then turns to Lisa. He smiles, but it’s a fragile thing. Then-

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: Cheese.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: We've...got some Stilton...Why don’t you...get that out?...Some grapes. Lisa is wrong footed. She looks to Tooley for support. He doesn’t meet her eye.

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: That'd be terrific. Hopkins smiles, relieved. Lisa colours; she is dismissed. She picks up the plates, glances at her husband and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa drops the plates into the sink and leans back against the draining board, trembling. On the table is a copy of the Daily Mail, it’s headline: FORD WOMEN FIGHT ON. Beneath it is a picture of a rally and a woman speaking out. There is something familiar about the woman. Lisa crosses and picks up the paper. Her face - as she sees it is Rita. EXT/INT. RITA’S HOUSE - DAY 86 Rita checks the temperature on the oven. Then she crosses to her bag which is on a chair beside the set kitchen table and removes her purse. It is empty. Her jaw tightens and she crosses to a cupboard near the door. Inside is a metal box, full of shoe polish, cloths and brushes. Also in there is a puncture repair kit. She opens this and reveals some crumpled notes and a few coins. She takes some of the cash, not all, and shoves it into her wallet. She grabs her bag and hurries into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. RITA'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Graham is coming downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: It’s in the oven. Don’t burn yourself-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wordlessly moves into the kitchen. And Rita pulls on a jacket. She turns and stops. Sharon is there. Her hair is in pig tails. One bunch is massively bigger than the other, while one is a tangled mess.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: Dad. Rita stares and goes towards her. Then she stops.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I gotta go see Albert. Just tell him to have another go. Sharon slips into the kitchen and Rita ties on a head scarf as Eddie comes down the stairs. She nods to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘s all ready... (crosses to placards against wall) You’re alright gettin’ ‘em off to school, aren't you? He watches her pick up the placards.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Course. She turns. Immediately he moves towards the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Eddie- (he stops) Everything’s okay, innit? He stares at her, then shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Why wouldn’t it be? She smiles, relieved and moves to the door. He watches her, then fingers the collar of his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is me last one.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Shirt. I just noticed.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (wrong footed) Yeah...Sorry. I missed washin’ Monday. I’1l do it tonight. He nods. And walks into the kitchen. A second. Rita stares at the empty doorway then leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls are queuing up for strike pay which Connie hands out from a table near the stage. There is much banter between the girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita passes Connie a sheet with names on it and removes one covered with signatures.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Thanks Rita- A young woman steps forward-

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: Monica Dawson-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: There you go- She passes her the list. She signs and then Rita hands her three notes. Monica stares at the money.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: It’s still three quid, love. Don’t matter how you count it!

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: I know...just...’bout covers me rent and that’s it-

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Hey, Mon; you’re short of anything, you just gotta ask- Eileen is next in line. Monica smiles, grateful. But then she shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: No. I’m alright. Thanks. I’1l manage.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: It’s all the Union can afford, Monica... She nods. She knows that. And she goes, slipping the money in her purse. Eileen steps forward-

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Eileen Scott. She bends over to sign. Brenda waits two or three girls behind her and lights a cigarette. She sucks greedily on the fag, then notices a woman waiting behind her, about thirty, looking longingly at the fag-

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: It’s me last one. Sorry, love. She shows her the empty packet. The girl smiles, disappointed. She nods, looks ahead, towards Connie. Brenda sighs. She takes her cigarette from her mouth, and tears it in two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lights one end against the other and then gives half to the girl who beams, delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monty stands with Grant and Hopkins. He tries to look confident. In fact, he’s uneasy. The whole room is. Then, suddenly, the door bursts open and Tooley strides in, a file under one arm. He slings it onto a far desk as Hopkins tries to assert control.

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: Monty. This is Mr Tooley. He-

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: I need you to break the strike for me, Mr Taylor...As soon as you can. Monty glances at Hopkins who also looks a little surprised. Monty scoffs.

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: I’m not sure you appreciate whose side I’m on-

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, I do. I’ve been going through your file-

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: File?

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: You’re on your side, Mr Taylor.

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon!? I- (to Hopkins) I don’t have to listen to this- He moves towards the door

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: Keep going! And six months from now, your union won't exist. Monty stops. Despite himself. He turns back.

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Industry can’t afford to pay women the same rates as men. Fact. If it’s forced to, it will collapse under the extra wage bill, its workers will be laid off, their union subscriptions will disappear and so, finally, will the unions which collect them. That’s you...Monty. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Which means you will no longer have a reason to visit these gentlemen here via- (flips open file) The Berni Inn, is it?...The Queen’s Head, The Chequers- (looks up) Jeez, that’s a lot’ve restaurants...Not to mention the all expenses paid trips to the party conferences. Union conferences- (spots something) To Paris! The Gallic rank and file. Good on you, Monty! Monty blinks; afraid. Tooley walks across and leans right into him.

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These women get what they want, you’re fucked. So why don’t you start thinking less about what your union can do for you and more what you can do for your union...Go break the strike! Monty trembles, humiliated, then walks numbly from the office. A long silence. Tooley looks to the others.

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Personnel files...Everyone’s got a weak spot. You just gotta find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women are now on picket before their entrance gates. They call out for Equal Pay, Equality... several chant; ‘We Want Justice!’ and ‘Support Our Struggle!’ A lorry delivering supplies turns away in support of them. the Women all cheer. The lorry pips as it drives back up the road. As the lorry accelerates away Rita sees a figure approaching-—

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Hello, love! Thought you weren’t comin’- (hands across money) Got your strike pay. Albert let me have it- Connie looks at it, takes it and nods. But she is hassled. She places her bag on the kerb beside several others, then steps across to join the chatting girls. Rita lowers her voice.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You alright?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah...Fine. Connie looks up the road. But she is aware of Rita staring at her; not convinced. Connie sighs, then steps back to rummage in her bag: a diversion. Rita moves over. Connie lowers her voice.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -Was a load've press outside the Labour Exchange. They cornered George... (Rita is confused) “Had he fought for a country where the women’d turn out to be more militant than the men?”-—

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Silly sods. Connie frowns; that’s not what she meant.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. But then, a bell sounds briefly. Rita looks across. A dark blue police van pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: What they doin’ here? Three or four policemen get out of the van.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Hello boys. Nothin’ too physical. Til we're on first name terms. I’m Brenda- The girls all laugh. A young PC, about twenty, speaks:

dialogues.speaker: COPPER
dialogues.text: You gotta move. The hilarity stops in an instant.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: COPPER
dialogues.text: You’re trespassin’.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: No, we ain’t. We're picketin’-

dialogues.speaker: COPPER
dialogues.text: You can’t. Not here.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Yes, we can. It’s our right!

dialogues.speaker: COPPER
dialogues.text: Not here! He is firm. The girls are stunned.

dialogues.speaker: COPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can do it at the bottom of the High Street-— (points way back to town) But this road, all the way back to town, Ford built. So it’s private property and since you’re on strike you’re actually out of contract which means you are trespassin’. You gotta move to the public highway-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: We can’t turn the lorries round from there-

dialogues.speaker: COPPER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry!...Look, who’s in charge? Everyone looks at Rita but Connie steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I’m shop steward- Rita turns, wrong footed-

dialogues.speaker: COPPER
dialogues.text: Right. I need you to get these women out of here. He nods and then opens his arms wide as if to corral the women up the road-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Get your hands off me-

dialogues.speaker: COPPER
dialogues.text: I ain’t touched you-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: It’s alright, Connie-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: No. It ain’t alright!

dialogues.speaker: COPPER
dialogues.text: (to Connie) Will you just move-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: No! Rita is worried, the situation starting to boil-

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Yeah, sod off! We ain’t doin’ nothin’ wrong- The women link arms. Connie is on the end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: COPPER
dialogues.text: You are! And you gotta shift! He shoves Connie forwards. She pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Get off me! You ignorant bugger-

dialogues.speaker: COPPER
dialogues.text: Right! Lads- He beckons the other coppers. And grabs Connie.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Leave her!

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE COPPER
dialogues.text: Get off! Come here- Connie kicks her heel hard into his shin. He cries out, letting go. But the other coppers grab her as the girls shove back against them. A huge melee ensues. The press take photos and Sandra tries to smile, even as she’s shoved one way and the other. In a moment, though, Connie, screaming, is extracted, shoved in the van and the coppers are away. Silence immediately falls and Rita looks to Brenda, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monty stands looking out of a window at the aftermath of the skirmish. A pay phone is close by, on the wall. Monty feels sick.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 68
dialogues.text: INT. CONNIE’S HOUSE - AFTERNOON 92 A clock ticks. And ticks. Then we see George. He sits at home. He is in an armchair but is perched right on the edge of the seat. He looks at the time. Then back to a spot on the far wall. He suddenly screws his eyes tight shut and grimaces. A second and he opens his eyes again. Wherever he is, he’s utterly terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenda, Rita and Eileen are all piled into the station and Rita speaks to the uniformed desk clerk. She is incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You can’t just keep her in.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: We can do what we like while she’s hysterical-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Course she’s hysterical! She’s been in a bleedin’ police cell all afternoon- (gathers her own emotions) Please. Just let me speak to her.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: She ain’t allowed visitors-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I’m not visitin’! I’m tryin’ to sort things out-

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Excuse me!...Can I help here? Tooley pushes through the women.

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I only just found out...A question of trespass, I gather? On Ford property?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: (pushing ID over) I represent Ford Motors, Sir, and we have no desire to press charges here. (Rita stares at Tooley, immediately uneasy) Protest is a basic right in all free and democratic countries.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: There’s also a matter of assault-

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: Is that so? Well, I’m quite sure it was a minor thing. And with all these ladies here as witnesses, plus the view of another of my employees who clearly saw the incident with the middle aged woman...I’m sure you’d be just as happy as me if it went right away. The clerk hesitates, then bolts from his desk into a back room. Tooley turns, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Robert Tooley, Mrs O’Grady. A pleasure to meet you. She’s shocked he knows her name. Then Tooley produces a card from an inner pocket. He holds it out-

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anytime you wanna come in, have a chat with me... (she takes the card) Talk about settling this thing- (she looks him in the eye) Just give me a call. (starts to go; looks back) It's my job to make things happen, Mrs O'Grady. I can make all sorts of things happen. And he’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Christ...I thought Boris Karloff was scary. Rita nods, gathering herself and her tumbling emotions.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: It’s fine. We can handle him...Shows how much they’re frightened of us...Sendin’ in the heavy brigade- A cheer of support. Rita makes to say more- But a voice cuts through.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Can we go now...I wanna go home. Connie is there; standing by an inner door which closes behind her. She is visibly upset. The girls flock to her. A half beat and Rita, a little awkward, goes, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 93A EXT. CONNIE’S HOUSE 93A Connie enters her house.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 70
dialogues.text: INT. CONNIE’S HOUSE - LATE AFTERNOON 94 Connie closes her door. She looks pale. A second as she gathers herself. Then she walks towards the sitting room, calling out, brightly-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I’m back, George- But there is no-one there, his chair empty.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: George? She passes into the kitchen. Nothing. And now she’s looking slightly anxious. She calls generally, to the house...

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m home, love- And she hurries from the kitchen to the stairs. We see her run up them.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: George! Then we hear her upstairs. Front bedroom, back bedroom and running back down the stairs. She looks scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George wanders across a bleak, barren expanse of open ground. His steps are jerky, ragged. He looks wretched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear shouts from the girls. They are calling George's name as they search the estate. Rita and Connie appear at the foot of a twitchell.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Christ-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: He’1l turn up-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I said. I said I’d be back at two-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Connie-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (shouts ) George!

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 71
dialogues.text: Rita looks stressed but knows she must remain calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham, still in school uniform, carrying a football, heads home. He frowns; recognising the figure sitting on a fly tipped bench. It is George. Graham moves over.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Hello Mr Andrews...You alright? George says nothing. There is a hint of spittle in the corner of his mouth. Graham is unsure. He glances round, then sits beside George.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just been playin’ football. I was Bobby Moore... (nothing from George) I should get home for me tea- He starts to move. But George reaches out and takes his hand. Graham is shocked at first; but then he looks into George’s eyes and sees the fear. And shock gives way to worry and he finally sits back, holding the older man’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connie, Rita, Eileen, Monica all crying out for George. And in them all we hear the gathering concern, the insistence.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, God! Where is he- She seems about to set off in another direction when she stops. Her breath catches. There he is. Walking with Graham. Graham still holding his hand. Graham bringing him home. Connie’s eyes fill and she runs towards her husband. Rita exhales, feeling the gathering pressure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon sits in the empty warehouse reading the paper. A man with a clipped ‘tash and severely parted hair stands to one side shouting into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Don’t you take that tone with me! I- (stops; listens; then-) There aren’t any! That’s what I’m sayin’: You've had ‘em all! There are no more finished seats...full stop! He slams the phone down. Then he takes a deep breath and gathers himself. He walks past Gordon who looks up from his paper.

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: Frank! Frank glances across

dialogues.speaker: GORDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do, then?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (matter of fact) Go home.

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: What? Frank stops by the door. He turns; looks serious-

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No more seats...no more job. Frank leaves. Gordon's face as he realises he’s being laid off. He is stunned. And angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The assembly line stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hopkins scrambles for his phone, terrified and dials-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pale Rita walks through Dagenham’s deserted streets. She is exhausted. But then, a man cycles up the hill. Then another. She checks her watch and frowns. Too early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But more sweep by until finally, a huge tide of cyclists pass by her. One or two men glance at her as they go. Finally, she stops an older man, moving slowly.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What’s goin’ on?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: You done it... (she is uncertain) They've laid everyone off- (she blinks) You’ve shut the factory down. He rides on. Rita wobbles.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I...I gotta see Albert. Rita runs off, through the tide of men flooding onto the streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tooley watches Hopkins who paces his office.

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: That's it. We’re buggered! We can’t make cars with no bloody seats in ‘em! He inadvertently snaps a pencil he’s holding. He throws it in the bin.

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: Relax-

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: Relax! The entire workforce of my main plant is going home!

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: Good. (Hopkins blinks) This is what we want- Tooley is smiling, reasonable. Hopkins, incredulous, makes to speak-

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're trying to make the girls go back to work. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And now, we've got five thousand men out of a job, as well...Their husbands and boyfriends...Which means, in a very short time, when those men can’t afford their booze and their soccer and their gambling...they’1l do our job for us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert and Rita stare at the facade from inside a CAFE. Albert still wears his Ford overalls. A note pad sits beside them on the table and several empty packets of crisps are screwed up in the ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Now’s the critical time, Rita. You gotta drive them girls forward-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I know that! She does. And he smiles, nodding, acknowledging it.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: You need to keep an eye on the Union, too. Now the lads’ve all been made redundant. They’1l be nervous. And Monty! Ford's rattled him. I can tell. So careful what news you share with him! She nods. Meets Albert’s eye. He suddenly smiles and clenches his fists.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold on tight, girl. INT. RITA’S HOUSE - NIGHT 105 Rita hurries into the house. She’s flushed.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I’m back- She nips into the kitchen which is in a mess. She opens the fridge. It is bare. There is a tiny piece of cheese and after checking it, she devours it. Then she walks towards the front room.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Eddie? She peers round the door. It’s empty.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 75
dialogues.text: INT. RITA’S HOUSE, BEDROOM - NIGHT 106 Rita slips into the bedroom. Eddie is laying in bed. He is reading a Haynes motorcycle Manual. He looks across and goes back to the book.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You alright?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yeah...Been busy, have you? She is instantly energized, moving to the bed and sitting close, her gaze intense.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Final push, Eddie; we gotta plan. The entire Main Plant closed down. Ford can’t afford that- He’s looking at her now and she stops; realises-—

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean...I’m sorry, love...It’s had to come to this. For you and the lads... He stares. Then looks back to the book.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Oh, don’t you worry about us, Rita...We was sayin’ on the way out, it’s nice warm weather at the moment; if they cut the gas off, we'll hardly notice. He glances back and smiles. Then, it’s face in the book again. Rita frowns. Is he joking? She stands and moves across the room and starts to undress. She turns to him, however; can’t let it go.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Thing is, I know how you feel, love: gettin’ laid off. ‘Cause’ve all them times us girls’ve supported you men; and it’s meant no work for us. He looks across the room. His eyes fiery. Half a second and he puts a lid on his emotions.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Then he’s back to the book. She stiffens even more.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: If you've got somethin’ on your mind, Eddie-

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I’m fine...I’d say. Beat. She crosses to take off her make up.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Good. Cause I ain’t had the easiest of days meself- Click! His half of the room plunges into darkness. Rita stares across at Eddie, sees his hand move from the lamp to the bed while his back remains resolutely turned towards her. INT. CONNIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 107 Connie is in bed, asleep. George is beside her. Suddenly he starts to pant. The panting gets louder and faster, as if he is hyperventilating. Connie moans, starts to wake.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Fuckin’ skip, fuckin’ skip-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: George-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Closin’ in! He’s...closin’- He shouts out. Connie turns on the light.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: George, George, stop it-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Ahh! Ah! He cries out the last time, wide awake. Then he sees it’s her. He blinks, starts to slow his breathing.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: It's alright. I’m here....It’s okay. She stares. He says nothing, whimpers. He looks at the bed. Then he curses, feeling something-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh... He shifts over. The bed is wet through.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: It don’t matter. I'll change it...Here- She drags him onto her side, towards the foot of the bed. He watches her. Then his face twists.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What the fuck do you care? (she is confused) You’d sooner they threw us in the sanatorium...Or the fuckin’ poor house-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (wrong footed) What?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (nodding; manic) I know what you’re up to...This strike. Back your mates...Then when we haven’t got a pot to piss in, with a bit’ve luck, the Social’1l have me, eh?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (upset) No! You-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And then you can move another one in...Real fuckin’ man...Look after you proper-—

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (angry) Don’t say that!-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Give you a bitta cock-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: George! A second and he launches himself at her-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You fuckin’ cow, you- He knocks her backwards and drags himself up her body. She immediately tries to pin his arms to his side but he is flailing, crying out, howling like an animal-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Stop it! George! Stop it! You’re gonna hurt me! And then we see him bite her, on the shoulder, like he is stuffing a rag in his own mouth. She cries out, in pain. But she grits her teeth, baring it. And finally, his wailing reaches a pitch and he slumps against her, spent and sobbing. Connie looks bereft, her own eyes filling immediately. She pulls him to her, holding his head against her chest. His convulsing body shakes the whole bed.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS
dialogues.text: 107aA

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry...I’m sorry- She holds him. And we pull back and see them both, huddled together, in their small dark bedroom. INT. HOPKINS OFFICE - DAY 107aA Tooley walks into the office where Grant is working. He is tense and opens a drawer aggressively. Grant closes a filing cabinet. Nothing. He sighs. But then he notices an old copy of the Dagenham and Redbridge Echo, folded on top of the cabinet. On it is a picture of Sandra, in hot pants.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Mr Tooley... Tooley turns, eyes greedy; he heard a thought there- INT. BRENDA’S HOUSE - AFTERNOON 107A Several of the women are hanging out at Brenda’s house. Monica and Eileen are making tea in the kitchen while Rita talks to a couple of women in the living room. Sandra reads a magazine, slightly distracted. Brenda gives out garden produce from a sack, handing a cauliflower to Eileen-

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Thanks love-

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: No! Thanks not necessary-— She deposits the cauliflower besides Monica

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -the pleasure was all mine. Eileen smiles. Then-

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Here, I don’t suppose you could get any fruit could you? I’ve had nothin’ but cabbage soup all week- Brenda smiles and opens a cupboard. Inside is nothing but a large pineapple.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Ta da!

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: Bloody hell-

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Jesus. He must love you- Monica steps closer, as if looking at the crown jewels-

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: I’ve never had a real pineapple.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Help yourself.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Go on. Eileen excitedly starts cutting it up. Brenda moves to Sandra.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cauliflower or cabbage?

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: What?... (realises what she’s being asked) Oh... No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Go on. Take something.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: No I’m fine. I got to go actually. She gets up finds her bag

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’1l see you all later. Monica enters as Sandra goes.

dialogues.speaker: MONICA, RITA, ETC
dialogues.text: See you Sandra.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: She alright?

dialogues.speaker: MONICA
dialogues.text: Course she is. You know what she’s like. Always wishing she was somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Brenda tips the sack upside down. One last cauliflower.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: This one’s Connie’s. Where is she? I ain’t seen her around- Eileen and Monica have brought out slices of Pineapple.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. I‘’1ll take it for her-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: No, I’11 do it... I wanna talk to her. Rita, clearly worried, slips the cauli in a straw basket.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Rita! It ain’t all your responsibility... Rita stares at Eileen and smiles. But it’s fragile.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: We gotta stand firm. Everyone of us! It ain't easy... And it’s gonna get harder now. Cause we ain’t caved in how they thought we would. Which means they’re desperate... But we’ve got this far, so we can get a bit further... as long as we stick together. She stops just as she’s getting into her stride, the others are trying to focus but really their attention is on the pineapple they are devouring with loud slurps and from which they look up at Rita. She sighs and smiles, relaxing at last.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Give us some of that-

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 113
dialogues.text: 114 EXT. REAR OF CONNIE’S HOUSE - AFTERNOON 114 Rita passes down the side of Connie’s house.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Connie...You there? She peeps over the wall. Connie is sitting on a chair by the door, a bucket at her feet, peeling potatoes. Rita smiles, stops straining and passes round the corner-

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I brought you a present. From Brenda’s fella- She ducks through the gate, holding out the Cauliflower. Connie looks across at her. Rita is still smiling. She places the cauliflower on the floor beside Connie.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Plus, Albert’s been in touch; Union’s called a meetin’- She straightens and looks at Connie

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sounds important; so we need to-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: No... (Rita frowns) I... I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (wrong footed)

dialogues.speaker: I...
dialogues.text: Connie avoids eye contact as she clarifies what she means.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I can come with you.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What? A beat. Finally Connie looks at Rita.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I...wanna step back a bit, Rita-

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS
dialogues.text: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 79aA

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (alarm now) Connie-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I need to...I feel like I- Rita is panicky.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You can’t just stop-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I’m not stoppin’! I’m still on strike. I still support you. I just- (Rita makes to speak) I can’t be on the front line so much!...That’s all.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (scared) But...we need you...at the meetin’s (shrugs ) And the younger girls; they look up to you-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: You’re in charge, Rita! You wanted to be in charge! Of this dispute. Rita looks upset by that one and it forces Connie to turn away. She sighs and tries another tack.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got arrested. They put us in a cell. It’s too much for me! Again they make eye contact. And this time Rita knows Connie’s making excuses. Connie sees this and exhales; unable to keep up the pretence any longer. She scoffs, sadly.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you want me to say, Rita? George is ill. You know that! He’s touched. And the strike’s whippin’ everything up...I gotta put him first- (Rita makes to speak) You don’t understand! (frowns ) I’m not his wife no more. I’m more like his...sister or- (stares at Rita) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I’m his. And that’s all he’s got left. Rita stares at her friend, her heart breaking.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: And I ain’t sayin’ you gotta give up on him, Connie. Just... (imploringly) You count, too. Your life...And you gotta allow it to blossom, just a bit...Or the war’s gonna destroy two people, Con! And that would be so wrong. Connie stares hard at Rita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandra stands very upright in the phone box. She looks agitated. The ‘phone rings and she grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Hello- (posher) Hello...Yes...Yes, it is...That’s right. I got your note, thank you. I was... busy when you come round- (stops; listens) What? (excited) Really...? (listens; then looks worried) Oh, I see...Well, I dunno, about that, I- (listens; brightens) Yeah? That would be nice...I mean, it makes sense, dunnit...Okay. Thank you. She hangs up. She looks dry mouthed. But set on a course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita walks through town. She approaches a large brick building: Department of Labour and Social Services, Employment Exchange. One or two men pass inside and several more are gathered in groups by the gate. Rita sees them, crosses the road, and accelerates. She slows at a bus stop. She lights a cigarette with unsteady hands. Then she stops. Someone is there; it is Gordon. She smiles, relieved.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Hello, Gordon-

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: Don’t you fuckin’ hello me! (she blinks, shocked) You don’t have to work. You got an husband. My missus don’t have to. You do, ‘cause it’s nice. It’s a bit extra. But you don’t have to...I have to fuckin’ work. To pay the electric and the food and the coal. The fuckin’ basics. Only now I can’t. I can’t shift what ain’t there...You fuckin’ idiot. He strides off. Rita doesn’t move, feeling sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita, shaken walks down the road, turns a corner and stops: from her house, two men are wheeling her fridge onto the back of a lorry. Eddie walks onto the doorstep, watching the scene. Rita hurries over and turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: We ain’t paid the HP... Last of my cash went on the electric bill. How you set? Her jaw tightens. INT. RITA’S HOUSE - AFTERNOON 120 Rita runs angrily into the kitchen. She goes straight for the shoe polish box, pulls out the puncture repair kit and opens it. It is bare. She looks furious-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 121 EXT. RITA’S HOUSE - AFTERNOON 121 Rita strides over to Eddie-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You spent the money-

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Eh?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You spent the last of the emergency. Out the repair kit.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I had to pay the milk man.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Why?-

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: What d’you mean-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: We could’a kept him off til next week-

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: He wanted payin’ !-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: And you shoulda told him we didn’t have it! (he makes to speak) Christ, Eddie, I’m in charge of the money!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Well, you ain’t much good at it are you! Or we might have some left! (she blinks, shocked; he scoffs) Welcome to the real world, Rita. This is bein’ on strike: you run out of cash and you end up screamin’ at each other. She stares at him, ashen.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What happened to you? Eddie walks back into the flat and Sharon walks out, oblivious to their argument. Rita stares.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: (Tugging at Rita’s sleeve) Mum, are you coming in now? Then her neighbour Marge lets herself in next door.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Rita! Rita turns;

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Hello, Marge. She smiles; doing her best.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: I thought you lot were back at work?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: No... no we... She looks at Marge

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everything alright?

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: Yeah it’s just... I was just finishing my shift and I’m sure I saw your Sandra... She stops and frowns-

dialogues.speaker: MARGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rita? Rita is already hurrying back to the house, Sharon gripped tightly in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Eddie! I gotta go out.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON
dialogues.text: But Mum... you said...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry love. Mummy’s got to do something important, Daddy will look after you (shouts ) Eddie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandra waits outside the factory. She looks nervous. She walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music plays quietly in the background as a photographer in his late forties, bearded, leans in towards Sandra. She wears an evening dress and long gloves. She is positioned between the harsh machinery of the shop floor and a brand new Ford Executive Saloon.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Terrific Sandra. Head a little higher.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Like that? She twists. Looks over one shoulder. She’s a natural.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Yeeees! Beautiful! And even as he says it, at the side, a door opens and Rita and the other girls rush in- PHOTOGRAPHER (CONT’D) Bit nearer...Flat hand on the roof. And they stop, amazed. They stare at Sandra. She looks extraordinary. Beautiful, transformed. And momentarily, they are neutered, unsure what to do. But then Sandra, as she turns, sees them. PHOTOGRAPHER (CONT’D) Okay. Openinin’ the door now. Lookin’ back to the machine’s- But Sandra slows, can’t do it with the girls watching. And finally she stops. Then the photographer becomes aware of the other women, too, Rita to the fore now. PHOTOGRAPHER (CONT’D) Right...Not to worry...Why don’t we have a break...You can go back to the caravan, Sandra. Get changed for the next set up!...You’ve done brilliantly. Sandra stares at the girls and then rushes out in the opposite direction, slipping on a silk dressing gown as she goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandra sits before a mirror, staring at herself. Then, in the mirror, she sees Rita enter at the back of the waggon. She turns. A moment.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: It’s all I’ve ever wanted.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I know. Sandra's eyes fill. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: I don’t really care about equal pay...Still a shitty factory, with dead birds and rain comin’ in and like a sauna in the summer and dirty and- (cries; screws up face) I want more, Rita- And now she’s crying. Rita runs across.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Hey- Rita comes across and hugs her. When Sandra speaks it’s between sobs-—

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Tooley said he’d shown me photo...Out the paper...And this photographer’d said I’d got what it took-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (fondly) You have-

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: It's for a brochure. Only trade but it could lead on...Foot in the door, you know- (breath catches) I don’t wanna let you down. I just-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You ain’t let us down. You ain’t gone back yet, have you...? (Sandra looks to Rita hopefully) I mean, that is the deal, innit? They let you do this shoot and you go back to work... but the going back bit ain’t happened yet so... She smiles. And then Sandra looks horribly compromised

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: But...They won’t use the photos, unless,

dialogues.speaker: I-
dialogues.text: She stops; the choice is clear.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Sandra...You look amazin’...I mean, you are a model. You were doin’ it, in there. They couldn’t get better...You could though...Now I seen it. You really could...But it’s up to you in the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita walks out. Sandra looks pale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The photographer, now back, glances across to Brenda and Eileen, nervously. And then Tooley suddenly appears. He looks worried. He sees the two women also, and fears the worst. But then, the far door opens and Sandra walks in. She looks scared but determined as she crosses the shop floor-

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Brilliant, Sandra. That’s great- He moves into position. Tooley looks triumphantly to Brenda and Eileen who stand with Sharon. PHOTOGRAPHER (CONT’D) Same as before. Loads’ve oomph, loads’ve energy... Sandra slips off the dressing gown PHOTOGRAPHER (CONT’D) Loads’ve, Christ-— He stops. Sandra is down to her bikini. And written on her body in red lipstick is: EQUAL PAY

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: How’s that look? Tooley trembles with suppressed rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The factory is deserted; shut down still and creaking with inactivity. INT. CONNIE’S HOUSE - DAY 129 George sits in the kitchen. He has the paper before him but doesn’t read it. Then Connie enters. She is dressed up and grabs a hand bag.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You’re goin’ are you? She turns. Frowns.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: You know I am. I said. It’s an emergency meetin’...Rita asked me to go, ‘special- (He stares. Nods) You gotta fight for what you believe in, George. You know that. More than anyone.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 88
dialogues.text: He stares.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You think I'd do the same again. If another war come round?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I know you would...Cause you’re an hero. He stares. There is utter conviction on her face.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I love you. She frowns. Wrong footed. Then there is a knock on the door. It opens.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Con. You all set?...George-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita smiles at George. Connie looks from Rita, back to her husband. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Go. She does and the door closes. George smiles again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita hurries into the outer chamber of the union offices, where we saw Albert wait for his bollocking.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Sorry I’m late- She stops. Connie is already sitting there, waiting, with Albert. Rita smiles, delighted that Connie’s back on board and she makes to speak. But before she can, Albert is to his feet and hurrying across-—

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: That don’t matter. You gotta listen- The door opens and a secretary appears

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Ready for you now... He leaves the doors open as he goes back inside the inner sanctum. We see Bartholomew, Rogers, Monty and a couple of other Union Reps waiting. Albert, placing his hands in the small of the back of Rita and Connie, turns the women in a wide arc towards the other room. At the same time he lowers his voice and continues in a whisper-

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: They've hung you out to dry. Lads in the other unions’ve had enough. Whatever they say now, don’t believe it and we’ll sort it out after- (normal voice, turning) This way, please, ladies- He guides the women into the main chamber. Albert smiles in a comradely way to the other men, then closes the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita’s jaw is fixed. She glances at Connie.

dialogues.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
dialogues.text: We are absolutely behind you still, Rita. You and the girls...We ain’t sayin’ otherwise-

dialogues.speaker: ROGERS
dialogues.text: And as you can see, we have got other representatives from the other Unions here to pledge-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You ain’t got ‘em all though, have you- Albert flashes her a glance. She bites it-

dialogues.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
dialogues.text: No...But we’re very confident we'll...prevail. The thing is, though, as we've got the National Conference comin’ up...down Weymouth...The most sensible thing, probably, would be just to go to a vote-—

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: Which would be the actual, final, and bindin’ position, I believe, Comrade? After which it’d be out our hands.

dialogues.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
dialogues.text: That's right, Monty. But like I say, we're expectin’ full support. He looks Rita in the eye. INT. BARBARA CASTLE’S WESTMINSTER OFFICES - AFTERNOON 132 The line up of Barbara Castle’s posh, public school, undersecretaries. They beam. Then we see Mrs Castle. She looks uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSECRETARY
dialogues.text: The Unions are turning!

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSECRETARY TWO
dialogues.text: The other unions, Minister! Normally, they all band together- She turns on that one-

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Yes. I gather it’s called Solidarity-

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSECRETARY
dialogues.text: Only, they’re not...Being solid. The men want to return to work. So they’re telling their unions to withdraw support from the machinist’s union and to actively put pressure on the women to end the dispute... (beams ) They’1l be back within the week. Barbara Castle stares. Is that a tiny hint of disappointment?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: We'll see... The men glance at each other, confused.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re assuming the girls will do as they’re told. She smiles and walks out of the room. EXT. CONNIE’S HOUSE - DAY 133 Rita and Connie pass down the lane. They are fired up.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: They must think we was born yesterday-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: That Monty’s a sly one, though, inni? (mocking) “Will the Weymouth vote be bindin’ Comrade?”

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (laughs ) See how he looks when we turn up down there! Put our side of things- They pass through the gate.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Sod him...You’re right. We can deal with him!

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: We can deal with anyone, Con! They both laugh and Connie opens the door. She screams. In the centre of the room, hanging from the ceiling, a belt around his neck, is George. He is wearing his RAF Best Blue. Rita makes a guttural, animal-like noise and then runs into the house. Connie follows, realising what Rita intends.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 91
dialogues.text: And Rita is there already, grabbing George round the thighs and trying to take the weight off his neck. EXT. CONNIE’S HOUSE - DAY 134 A police car and an ambulance are parked on the road. A small crowd has gathered to watch. Rita is standing a little away from the scene, staring at the house. She can see Connie, through the front windows, on the settee, a blanket around her shoulders, being passed a cup of tea by a policewoman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The machinists are all gathered for George’s funeral. A couple of RAF greatcoats can be seen. Possibly ex crew...they’re George’s age. Connie stands with Brenda. Rita is with Eddie and the kids. Albert is there, too. The service nears its end and finally, the vicar closes his prayer book and moves away. The crowd presses up to Connie and people start to pass on their condolences.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Connie. Connie nods, smiles, but doesn’t look Rita in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: No, you’re not.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: You thought he was a millstone. You thought he was keepin’ me back- One or two heads turn.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Hey, Connie that’s enough! Connie finally looks at Rita.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I should have been there. Brenda leads Connie away. She has started to cry. Rita watches, her expression frozen. Eddie takes her hand supportively. EXT. RITA’S HOUSE - EVENING 136 Rita is alone now. We sense she’s not been home all afternoon. She walks slowly onto her street, exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then she stops. A car is parked close to her house. Lisa's. She climbs from the vehicle and smiles. Rita does her best to return the gesture as she reaches the car.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: This is a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m...sorry it’s so late...I nearly didn’t come at all. She’s nervous. Rita is too numb to see it.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You wanna pop in? I...be honest, I ain’t feelin’ the most chatty but-

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: No...I really don’t want to keep you, I just- She looks at Rita; and loses her nerve. She smiles instead.

dialogues.speaker: LISA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr Clarke has been asked to leave the school. (Rita frowns; the name cuts through) We won. They’re getting rid of him. Rita manages to smile.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: That's great. That’s...brilliant. Lisa nods. A beat. Rita looks to her front door-

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I’m married to Peter Hopkins. At the factory... (Rita is stunned) Had a feeling you didn’t know...And I didn’t know...who you were...the strike. She nods emphatically and smiles. Rita frowns.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I...don’t understand. I- (suddenly upset) If you’ve come here to tell me to back off...I wasn’t jokin’; what’s gone on today and I’m warning you-

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Keep going! Please. Please keep going. Rita looks down. Lisa has gripped her wrist. Then Rita looks back into Lisa’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LISA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you know who I am, Rita? (Rita is confused) Who I actually am? I’m Lisa Burnett. I’m thirty one years old, with a first class honours degree from one of the finest universities in the world and my husband treats me like I’m a fool. Rita blinks and Lisa smiles, fondly-

dialogues.speaker: LISA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When I studied...for my degree...I was...very nappy AE)

dialogues.speaker: LISA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All sorts of reasons...Especially the work...I loved to read about all these extraordinary people. Making history. I always wondered what it felt like... (nods ) Let me know will you...When you’ve finished doing it. (kisses her on the cheek) Don’t let me down. She gets into the car and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 93
dialogues.text: INT. RITA’S HOUSE - EVENING 137 Rita passes into her bedroom. She stares out of the window. And suddenly, she starts to cry. Great sobs which she bites back as she tries to keep quiet. And gradually, as she clenches her fists, she manages to calm herself. She takes a deep, steadying breath. Then she crosses the room and looks at herself in the dressing table mirror. She is a mess. A second and she grabs a hanky, licks it and removes her smudged make up. Another beat. She stares at herself, determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie’s motorcycle is loaded with camping kit. He pushes himself back from under the side car and stares at Rita incredulously.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You’re goin’? To Weymouth? Then he looks back to his wife. She says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s...the holiday, it’s...campin’. We go campin’-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I can't-—

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Why can’t you-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Because- (gritted teeth) If I don’t see it through...Then it has all been for nothin’... She stares at him. Then she picks up her case and walks off down the street. He watches. His chest heaves. But then, he looks compromised. And he calls out-

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Rita! He runs after her.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rita!l- He catches her up. She turns.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: We gotta sort this out. Now! (she makes to speak) No...We have and...I know it ain’t been good...between us lately- (again she tries to speak) Which...I ain’t about to make worse, I promise, only...We gotta stop the rot or-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (weary) Eddie-

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Listen to me! His impassioned expression slows her. He focuses.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look. If I ain’t...appreciated what you done, properly...how you’ve come on and...what you’ve achieved, all that...then I’m sorry- She doesn’t want this; looks down the road.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I gotta catch a bus-—

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Rita! I am sorry...But you ain’t been perfect in all this either, you know...I mean, just cause you believe ina particular thing with all your heart, that don’t mean it actually is the most crucial thing in the whole world...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: This really ain’t the time, Eddie-

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yes! It is! Cause it needs sayin’! I know you reckon I’m not bothered about the important things and I just...drift along and I’m more interested in fiddlin’ with motorbikes and makin’ tents out of head rest covers but...I do me best. You know? (scoffs) Christ, I’m not out on the beer every night or...screwin’ other women, or- (a thought) I’ve never once raised me hand to you! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ever. Or the kids. And- (He stops. She is smiling) What? Why you lookin’ like that?-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You’re a saint. That’s what you’re tellin’ me, Eddie? You’re a bleedin’ saint! Cause you give us an even break... (thunderous ) That's as it should be...Jesus! What do you think this strike’s been all about? It ain't about us gettin’ special treatment, you know...Kid gloves...It’s been about fairness. What’s proper....And you stand there now and lecture me about countin’ me blessin’s... (nods ) Well, you’re right actually...You don’t knock us about, you don’t drink, you don't gamble, you do join in with the family... (through gritted teeth) That 's-as-—it-should-be!...Try and understand that. Please. What you’re talkin’ about now...what I’ve been fightin’ for, the last few weeks...Same thing...Rights. Not privileges. She marches off and Eddie watches her go. He sways, as if he has taken a punch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last of the girls climbs onto a coach. Rita looks back at the streets of Dagenham and climbs on also-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coach is full. Rita’s seat is at the front as usual. The seat next to her, Connie’s, is empty. Rita catches Brenda’s eye and then she sits, alone. INT. RITA’S HOUSE - LATE AFTERNOON 141 Eddie sits at the kitchen table, thinking. He looks shocked. He blinks, noticing the unpacked camping gear leant against a couple of protest placards. He exhales slowly. But then, Graham enters the room. He sits next to his father. Eddie looks at him. Graham smiles. It’s fine. A long moment and Eddie straightens.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 96
dialogues.text: EXT. NEIGHBOUR’S HOUSE - LATE AFTERNOON 142 The kids stand with a woman on her doorstep and wave as Eddie zooms off on his motorbike. He doesn’t wave back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hotel with a plush facade, displaying a sign: The Tadmarton Park Hotel, Weymouth, Dorset Welcomes The Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ballroom is crowded with Union delegates as the Chair, up on stage, a northerner, consults his notes.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: Very good, gentlemen. And that brings us to our main item...The ongoing dispute at Ford Motors...Can I call on Monty Taylor, Senior Convenor, Ford Dagenham. The chairman squints. And out of the darkness comes Monty. He mounts the stage and moves across to the Chair. He whispers and then crosses to the lectern.

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: Thank you Mr Chairman...I shall try and be brief- He looks to the darkened hall, a glint in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie jumps off his bike and looks wildly round: Shit! The seafront is a mass of hotels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monty is pushing on, scared, but desperate.

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: -Of course we must represent all our members...But me must also remember we live in a democracy. And in a democracy, the wishes of the majority must always hold sway. Therefore-

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Monty Taylor! You two faced, hypocritical, toe rag!

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 97
dialogues.text: A kerfuffle by the door. Monty squints into the darkness. The lights come on. The Dagenham contingent are there, Eileen by the switch, banners at the ready.

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: Now hang on-

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: No, you hang on- More rowdiness and shouts of Judas. The whole hall hums. Several delegates stand to see what’s happening. Monty has moved to the front of the stage and calls out for the girls to sit down and that he’1ll explain, while they cal back at him. Finally Monty returns and shouts into the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: Be quiet! The noise shocks everyone into silence. Monty is embarrassed and moderates his voice. MONTY (CONT’D) Sorry...Gentlemen...We’1l sort this out amongst ourselves later-

dialogues.speaker: SCOTSMAN
dialogues.text: (shouts; stands) Hey, Monty! I’ve seen more of their mugs on the front pages these last few weeks than you’ve managed in twenty years! (laughter from crowd) I wouldnae mind hearin’ from ‘em. Shouts of support. Monty looks terrified.

dialogues.speaker: MONTY
dialogues.text: No- More shouts of support. Monty shakes his head. EXT. SEAFRONT —- EVENING 147 Eddie walks down the seafront and stops. Parked up ahead is a coach...From Dagenham. He runs past it and into the Hotel outside which it is parked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More shouts. Monty looks trapped. Then the sound of slow stamping and clapping. Louder and louder. Then Brenda, Eileen and the others step aside. Rita is there. She walks towards the platform. And Monty looks sunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie looks for a sign and runs towards the doors which lead into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie bursts into the hall and stops right at the back. Rita is at the lectern, a light on her. All around is still. She makes to speak then stops, gathering herself; all of the emotion of the last few days sweeping over her. She stares at the people in the hall, their faces turned to her. Waiting...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: My best friend lost her husband recently. Durin’ the war he was a gunner in Fifty Squadron in the RAF. He got shot down one time...on a raid to Essen and even though he managed to bail out, he was badly injured. I asked him once, why he’d joined the raf and he said...they got the best women... (Laughter in the hall. She nods, upset) Which they did... Eddie stares at Rita

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But then he said, you had to do somethin’. And he’d always wanted to go up in a plane... Her jaw tightens; she feels the cause start to flood through her veins.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You had to do somethin’...That was a given. Cause it was a matter of principle. You had to stand up; do what was right, ‘cause otherwise you wouldn’t be able to look yourself in the mirror. (stares at hall) When did that change?
