When did we, in this country, start bein’ happy, to do nothin’? On what day did we decide we had no duty to fairness no more? (The hall is silent. She nods slightly) It has NOT changed. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That is NOT us...It is not you...And we are only in this situation now, where women get paid less money than men for doing the same work... (lets it sink in. Nods) -because we was tricked. Those in power kept tellin’ us: it’s fine. You don’t need to do the right thing cause there’s nothin’ needs fixin’. And they said it for so long, we ended up believin’ it was right....Well it ain’t right! Calls of support. Heads nod in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was wrong at the start, it’s wrong now, and it’ll be wrong forever!- (shouts of agreement) -unless you back us, you stand up, you remember who you are and you accept, that this is a matter of principle. Women are entitled to the same rates of pay as men. And that is it. No matter the cost, no Matter the difficulty, no matter them that are gonna lose out, no human being should be punished in the workplace cause’ve how they was born! (Cheers. Rita calls above them-) We are the working classes. The men and the women. We are the furnace which fires the world and without us no-body earns tuppence h’appenny! (big cheer) We are not separated by sex, only by the will of those who are not prepared to go into battle for what is right - and those who are! The hall erupts. And leaps to its feet. Eddie sways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delegates pour out, talking excitedly about what they have just witnessed. We briefly see Eddie again, swallowed up by the crowd, being pushed backwards. And then we see our girls, emerging thrilled and elated. We hear odd snatches of conversation above a huge wall of chatter-

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: (to another woman) I’m tellin’ you! You can see ‘em! Scorch marks right up the curtains where Monty’s arse caught fire- The woman laughs. Rita smiles. Her chest still heaves. Eileen grabs her wrist.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Come on, let’s have a drink-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: We got no money-

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: We’re all signin’ it to Monty’s room- The girls laugh. The scots delegate pats Rita on the back. Some speech. Rita nods, but she is exhausted. Brenda smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Hey! Come on...You’re allowed to unwind a bit, you know

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (nods ) Yeah. ‘Cept we ain’t there yet, Brenda- She stops. She is looking over Brenda’s shoulder, to the other side of revolving doors, where she can see, on the spot where he has been spat out, Eddie. He stares in at Rita. Then, suddenly, he turns and hurries off-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita runs after the retreating Eddie. She calls out to him.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Eddie...Eddie! (he finally stops; turns) What you doin’ here? He looks at her; slightly confused. Then...

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I...come to say sorry. I mean...I thought...about what you said and- (shrugs ) You’re right, I suppose...You are right. (nods ) And it is amazin’ what you done...Rita O'Grady. And I wanna back you...I was gonna tell you that. Only then I come in when you was speakin’ and I heard you and...you was...huge...you was...like a force- He can’t express it. Then he looks at her fondly and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And then I thought... (shrugs ) Not sure me backin’ you makes that much difference to be quiet honest. Where you are now... (serious; positive) Anyway. You get back to your meeting or whatever you gotta do. I should... He nods, vaguely over his shoulder and sets off, walking-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Eddie! He turns again. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’ve said some stupid things in your time but... She runs to him, embraces him and kisses him hard on the mouth. She steps back. He looks stunned.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of course you backin’ me makes a difference. It makes all the difference in the world. She kisses him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Castle is holding back the slightest of smiles. She is looking at a sheet of paper on her desk while the undersecretaries wait in a line.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: “The bloody unions are back in line”-

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSECRETARY
dialogues.text: It’s verbatim.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSECRETARY TWO
dialogues.text: Our man was there.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Well, well, well- (looks to them) So the strike remains solid. And meanwhile, five thousand men have now been laid off and the country has lost export orders worth 8 million pounds... (checks notes) 8 million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks back to the undersecretaries.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSECRETARY TWO
dialogues.text: It really does seem time to call in Sir Jack.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Good...I‘’1l1 do that then. I’1l appoint a Court of Inquiry, which he can oversee. And let’s hope that does the job. She smiles. The men glance at each other and stand.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. And one other thing...Set up a meeting will you.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSECRETARY
dialogues.text: Minister?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: With the machinists. Their leaders. The men glance at each other.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSECRETARY
dialogues.text: Pardon me?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: I want to meet them. At my St James's Square Offices...At the earliest opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSECRETARY
dialogues.text: But— Mrs Castle looks at them quizzically. Yes?

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSECRETARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The Minister doesn’t. Do that. Never has done.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSECRETARY TWO
dialogues.text: It'll just encourage them.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSECRETARY
dialogues.text: Give credence to their cause. She looks at them. Long beat. She inhales. Then:

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: I’m what’s known as a fiery red head...I hate to make this a matter of appearance...go all womanly on you but...there you have it. And me standing up like this- (gets to her feet) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is in fact, just that red headed fieriness, leaping to the fore... (voice rises furiously) Credence! I will give credence to their cause? My God. Their cause already has credence. It’s equal pay. Equal pay is common justice. And if you weren’t such a bunch of egotistical, chauvinistic, bigoted dunderheads, you’d realise it-

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: This is an office run by incompetents. And I am sick and tired of being patronised, spoken down to and generally indulged as if I was the May Queen! (one of the men holds up a tremulous finger, as if to make a point-) Set up the meeting! The men scatter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tooley glares-

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: Whaddya mean, The Secretary of State is gonna see the women? On whose say so? Hopkins faces Tooley; scared.

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: On her own, I gather...Apparently, Mrs Castle’s quite a forceful woman-

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: Is she! He marches across the office and picks up his phone.

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: What’re you doing-?

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: I represent Ford Motors. We are the biggest car manufacturer in the world. We pump millions of pounds into the UK economy... he dial (he *tWORE)

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think it’s time my bosses started reminding one or two people of that fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie’s motorcycle pulls up outside Rita’s house. Albert waits by the door. Rita looks concerned and quickly jumps out of the side car, hurrying over to him. For once he doesn’t look entirely in control of his emotions-

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: There’s no need to panic, Rita. Only I’ve had a call...From Mrs Castle’s office- Eddie is clambering off the bike but turns suddenly as he hears a sharp scream of excitement. He looks down the drive to Rita who is turned to him, an expression of sheer delight on her face-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Bloody ‘ell! She grins, thrilled! INT. RITA’S HOUSE - DAY 155 Now Rita looks concerned as she roots through her wardrobe. She pulls out a dress and turns, holding it up. Albert sits on a chair beside Eddie, Eddie still in his bike gear, sitting on the bed, both gazing across at the impromptu fashion show like rabbits caught in a full headlight glare.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Too short. She nods in agreement. Then she looks back and selects another outfit. This she holds up.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Too formal. She nods and she grabs another. She holds this up. But this time she doesn’t say anything. She looks to the lads. Albert jumps at the opportunity-

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Lovely...that is... (to Eddie) Innit? That’s-

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. They both nod. Her face falls

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You hate it... She looks back to the wardrobe. The lads glance at each other appalled.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I ain’t got anythin’ that’s right- And then Rita stops; has an idea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hopkins is back at home. He stares sickly at the front page of the Telegraph which records the ongoing horror of Ford's plummeting sales figures. Then the door bell rings. Hopkins waits for Lisa to answer. But it rings again. He sighs and stands, crossing to the door. He opens it. Rita. He is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: S’'alright. I ain’t come to see you. It’s your missus I wanna talk to. Lisa steps forward from behind Hopkins.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Rita...What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: Rita?!

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I need a favour. Hopkins is agog. Lisa nods.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Come inside-

dialogues.speaker: HOPKINS
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Lisa-

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: What!?

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 105
dialogues.text: Her look is hard; combative. He has not seen it before. She holds his gaze, furiously and he steps meekly to one side. Rita enters the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold Wilson puffs on his pipe as his official motor sets off around St James’s Square. Mrs Castle settles next to him, having just got in. Wilson looks tense and when Mrs Castle raises an enquiring eyebrow, he gets straight to it-

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD WILSON
dialogues.text: Have you or have you not invited the Ford women to your offices? Mrs Castle hesitates, momentarily. Then:

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Prime minister-

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD WILSON
dialogues.text: I have just spent the last half an hour on the phone to Henry Ford the Second, reassuring him that my government is not on the side of the strikers-

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: It’s not a question of sides. We have to grasp the nettle-

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD WILSON
dialogues.text: By aligning ourselves with the machinists? (she makes to deny this) I wanted you to fix this! Not to make it worse-!

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: And I will fix it! If you’d just... (can’t help it) Bloody well support me! This shocks them both. But Wilson can see her passion. He nods. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can resolve this dispute. I can get the women working again... but I am going to have to tell them that I agree with their cause. He understands instantly-

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD WILSON
dialogues.text: No. Barbara, please-

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS
dialogues.text: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 105aA

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: You know their right. He sighs; his shoulders slump.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD WILSON
dialogues.text: Now is not the time-

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Harold, we talked about this in the nineteen fifties, You were adamant-—

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD WILSON
dialogues.text: I wasn’t running the country then! She looks away. Disappointed in him. He sighs. Long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAROLD WILSON (CONT’D) See the women. If that’s what you want to do. (she starts to speak; grateful) But! Whatever you do, do not upset Ford! I’m enough trouble with the Americans as it is. She nods, knowing that she is on a tightrope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita strides through Dagenham. Pull back. She wears Lisa’s Biba dress. Ahead, the other girls wait for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rather splendid exterior of Mrs Castle’s offices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The undersecretaries are struggling with a sofa. They put it down, then straighten. They are sweating.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: There. Perfect...Actually...Maybe it was better where we had it before- (The men exchange glances) Oh...dizzy me. The men stagger back with the sofa and she turns away. Up close we see she is nervous. She looks back-

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just the armchairs, then... (she disappears from view) And I want plenty of sherry.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 108
dialogues.text: EXT. BARBARA CASTLE’S WESTMINSTER OFFICES - DAY 163 The girls walk towards St James’s Square, followed by the press. A second crowd of photographers and a camera crew, already in-situ, rush forwards to envelop them. Behind, the press who have dogged them all day, also shove forwards and a scrum ensues. Before long, one or two of the girls look overwhelmed and panicky.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: If you could just...can we get through please- (she, too, is struggling) You’re blockin’ the way. You-

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Make some room, for God’s sake- Rita stops. Looks across. Connie is coming towards her, shoving reporters aside.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Connie- The door opens and an undersecretary steps out.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSECRETARY
dialogues.text: Ladies. Good morning...Could you keep back please, gentlemen- He and a couple more of the staff shove the press back.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I’m late. The two women stare, Rita’s eyes fill. They embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 163 Cont.EXT. BARBARA CASTLE’S WESTMINSTER OFFICES - DAY

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER TWO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Rita! Rita! Can we have a final comment-

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER THREE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Rita-

dialogues.speaker: I-
dialogues.text: All of the girls are through the cordon and the reporters are pushed back. But still they look formidable-

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER TWO
dialogues.text: Rita! Is equal pay really a possibility?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER THREE
dialogues.text: What if Mrs Castle says no deal?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER TWO
dialogues.text: How will you cope?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Cope? How will we cope? She is aware of Connie beside her. Eileen, Sandra and Brenda, too. Rita looks back to the reporter.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We’re women. Now don’t ask such stupid questions. Rita turns to Connie and leads the girls back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Castle checks the room; with sofas and armchairs arranged in a circle it now looks like a living room rather than a meeting place. She takes a deep breath and crosses to a large armoire at the back of the room. She opens it and selects a jacket from her closet. She plumps for something rather old. She looks at herself in the door mirror. Very sober. Then she checks shoes. The pair we've seen on several occasions are discarded and a plainer pair popped on. There is knock on the door. An under secretary comes in

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSECRETARY
dialogues.text: Minister, there’s a slight problem. Mrs Castle turns to the secretary. INT. BARBARA CASTLE’S WESTMINSTER OFFICES - DAY 164A Mrs Castle walks into a smaller room. A man stands with his back to us. He turns, it’s Tooley.

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: Mrs Castle.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Mr Tooley - I wasn’t expecting you. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: But you are meeting the women?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: I think it’s time I listened to their argument. If you’d care to wait I'll inform you of any decisions we make. She turns. Tooley watches her; his jaw suddenly tightens-

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: You know, we basically want the same thing, Mrs Castle...you and I- She stops and turns

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We want to see Ford Motors employing British workers.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Ford is a vital part of our economy, I’m well aware of that-

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: Then don’t make us go elsewhere to build our cars... It wobbles her. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you don’t help us hold the line here and support us in our efforts to combat the constant strikes which undermine our ability to make cars at a profit...we will take our factories elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: MRS CASTLE
dialogues.text: Are you threatening me, Mr Tooley?

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: I’m just trying to stop 40,000 people from losing their jobs, Mrs Castle. That's how many people we employ in this country...Neither of us wanna take that risk...surely? She holds his gaze. Then she turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Castle closes the door behind her and takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenda and Sandra look out of a window, pointing out the sights. But they’re nervous. As is Connie who glances to the door. But Rita, who is beside her, sitting on a sofa, can concentrate only on her friend. Finally-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Connie- Connie turns. Rita speaks with a hushed voice. She smiles. Then fudges it-

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks for comin’.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 110B
dialogues.text: Connie smiles. And Rita immediately leans closer in-

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry-—

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: No! Don’t. It’s me that needs to apologise- (Rita frowns) I loved George. More than anything. But he’s gone now. And it’s the right thing. I thought that straightaway. And I felt guilty...and I took it out on you but... (nods head) He ain’t sufferin’ and...he is better out of it. I know that...Deep down. And you gotta trust them feelin’s. Ain’t you? Gotta follow your gut...You taught us that. Rita is amazed but before she can react, the door is opened and an undersecretary is there.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSECRETARY
dialogues.text: The Minister will see you now- The women all look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk into the main office where Mrs Castle is waiting in front of the grand fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Mrs Castle? She turns and smiles

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: I am...And you’re Mrs O’Grady. I recognise you from the news. She crosses and they shake.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I’m pleased to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: And me, you. Mrs Castle looks to the others.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Sorry. This is Connie, Brenda and Sandra.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: I’m delighted you could all come They all nod. Mrs Castle’s brain is racing.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please take a seat. Would you care for a sherry? Mrs Castle, nods to a strategically placed undersecretary.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: You ain’t got whiskey, have you? The girls look to Brenda thunderously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tooley is waiting still. He is brought a second cup of tea. He looks irritated.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSECRETARY
dialogues.text: Sugar?

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: No. The undersecretary takes the empty and leaves the full cup. Tooley looks to the door. All alpha male

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Castle places her jacket on her chair. She’s delaying. Then she turns to Rita who sits directly opposite, a small table between them.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: I’ve been following your dispute very closely. And I want to say how proud I am of the battle you’ve fought. I fully support the struggle for equal pay. The girls look to each other, flushed with hope.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you will have it...But in time.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Industry is going to object. The Lords’11l kick up a fuss. The press’ll have a field day...It isn’t going to be easy-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What is, that’s worth havin’? Mrs Castle makes to retort then stops and considers the girls. This is difficult. But she drives on-

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Return to work, get back to your machines and then you have my word that I will push forward with your fight-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: No! The girls were all thinking it but Rita’s vehemence still surprises.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Mrs O’Grady-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: That ain’t good enough- (Barbara makes to speak) We want somethin’ now! Somethin’ solid-

dialogues.speaker: MRS CASTLE
dialogues.text: But-—

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You got the authority, you- (upset) We thought...seein’ you, we’d-

dialogues.speaker: MRS CASTLE
dialogues.text: In politics you sometimes have to play the long game-

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: We ain’t politicians! We’re workin’ women. And so are you! Mrs Castle blinks. Rita too. A beat. Then Mrs Castle straightens.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Very well. What would it take...? To get you back.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: The something solid...And mark well, I say some thing, not everything.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: We'd need...guarantee of an Equal Pay Act and...an immediate and...considerable movement towards the male rate at Ford. Mrs Castle considers them. Her eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Seventy five per cent?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Ninety. Mrs Castle’s eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: You’re putting me in a very difficult position... 167A INT. BARBARA CASTLE’S WESTMINSTER OFFICES ANTE ROOM Mrs Castle closes the door behind her. Her brain races. She turns to an undersecretary in the room.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Get me the Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 111AA
dialogues.text: He picks up the phone. Mrs Castle's jaw tightens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tooley waits, fidgeting. An undersecretary sticks his head round the door with a teapot and an enquiring expression.

dialogues.speaker: TOOLEY
dialogues.text: Whadd’ya think? The undersecretary ducks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women sit on the edges of their seats and wait. Rita feels self conscious.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I wasn't too...aggressive?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Naah. (looks to Sandra) They have got rid of hangin’ ain't they? Connie simply squeezes Rita’s hand. INT. BARBARA CASTLE’S WESTMINSTER OFFICES, ANTE ROOM - 16

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The undersecretary puts down the phone.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSECRETARY
dialogues.text: He’s on a plane. Won’t land until this evening. Mrs Castle says nothing. Just exhales, slowly. Then she looks to the opposite ends of the room. Two doors. Two choices. She takes a deep breath. INT. MRS CASTLE’S WESTMINSTER OFFICES - DAY 167E Mrs Castle strides into Tooley’s room. Tooley immediately makes to speak- but Mrs Castle gets there first.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: That risk; you were talking about, Mr Tooley. I’m going to have to take it. (he frowns) All women are entitled to equal pay and I intend to begin the process of enshrining that fact in law. Whatever the cost. (Tooley is ashen) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, the question is...do you want to wait until it is Law before you get your machinists back to work, or do you want to make a gesture now and see production resume immediately? Tooley stares at Mrs Castle. Endgame. Who will back down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eileen, Monica and the other women wait patiently with their banners. Albert appears and dispenses beers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women stare at empty glasses. Brenda takes a pull on her whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: I’m gonna miss all this. The girls smile but they’re so nervous. And then the door opens. All heads turn and Mrs Castle walks slowly into the room.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: We have a deal.
Suddenly, Barbara looks uneasy. She shakes her head. The girls look worried.
Rita is stunned. She sees Mrs Castle’s twinkling smile. And she, along with the girls, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Thank you! Mrs Castle grabs a glass and toasts with Rita. Brenda smiles and looks to Connie who is grinning, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women look tired as well as happy as they walk into the sunlight. Mrs Castle stops as they are greeted by camera flashes, and turns to Rita.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: That's Biba... I saw it in a magazine- Rita nods to Mrs Castle’s outfit.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: And that’s C and A. I’ve got one at home... Seems we all dressed up... And you dressed down... Who did that put at an advantage do you think? Mrs Castle laughs.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After you.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Oh, no, young lady. After you. Mrs Castle indicates that Rita should step forward first. And Rita moves towards the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black and white TV footage. Mrs Castle stands with the girls. She clears her throat.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA CASTLE
dialogues.text: Thank you...Thank you very much...I’m delighted to say that following our talks this afternoon, getting down to the nitty gritty, the 187 Ford machinists will be going back to work on the lst of July. They will get an immediate pay rise of 7d an hour which will put them at 92% of the male rate. However, this is not an end to it. As a result of our discussion, I can announce that the government is fully committed to the creation of an Equal Pay Act and by the Autumn of this year, I guarantee appropriate legislation will be put into place to ensure that that act becomes law. She steps back. Cameras flash and reporters call out. Rita breathes deeply, absorbing the scene.

dialogues.speaker: 10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 114
dialogues.text: She places her arms around Connie and with Sandra and Eileen and Brenda, they form up as a group. They all beam. SNAP. And the picture freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The deserted factory. But then a bike comes over the hill. A single bike. A woman is on it. Then comes another and another. The women are leading the workforce back and soon the whole road is awash with bikes and people, all buffeted together, a vast sea of humanity, sweeping down the road, back to their jobs.
